YC_OneLiner: INDIVIDUAL transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through plastic credit verification, serving municipalities and local government, targeting 18,000 tonnes annually
Technologies: Chemical depolymerization | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs: Conventional plastic production relies on petrochemical extraction, a multi-stage process involving crude oil refining, cracking hydrocarbons into monomers, and polymerization. This pathway is energy-intensive, emitting significant CO₂ and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). In contrast, Griska’s recycling model bypasses petroleum extraction by recovering post-consumer plastics, particularly hazardous pesticide containers, and disinfecting them for safe reuse. This eliminates the need for incineration or open burning, which typically releases dioxins, furans, and microplastics into the environment. Recycling consumes up to 80% less energy than virgin plastic production and reduces lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 2.5 tonnes of CO₂ per tonne of recycled plastic. By establishing aggregation centers across Lusaka’s 94 compounds, Griska creates a closed-loop system where plastics are collected, sanitized, and reprocessed into raw materials. This systems-based approach reduces po
Bold_Characteristics: Griska is bold because it tackles one of Africa’s most urgent crises, plastic waste, through an integrated, scalable, and inclusive model. Zambia generates over 1.2M tonnes of solid waste annually, with plastics making up nearly 14%, much of it unmanaged in Lusaka’s 94 compounds. In rainy seasons, clogged drains from discarded plastics worsen floods, displacing families, damaging infrastructure, and forcing government to spend millions yearly on recovery. By disinfecting hazardous pesticide containers and recycling plastics, Griska prevents toxic emissions from burning, reduces soil and water
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic pollution is a growing crisis in Zambia. On farms, pesticide containers are often burned or discarded, releasing toxic chemicals into the soil and air. In Lusaka, a city of 2.3 million people, over 62% live in 94 compounds where waste management is limited, and thousands of tonnes of plastic end up in the environment each year. Current small aggregators exist, but their reach is minimal compared to the scale of the problem.

Griska is solving this by disinfecting and recycling pesticide
Beneficiaries: Griska benefits collectors through income, manufacturers through cheaper inputs, government through reduced costs, and communities through cleaner, safer environments, delivering impact across the entire ecosystem.
Team_Info:

With over 15 years of expertise in operations management, project management, systems implementation, marketing, and business development, Sydney brings the same vision and discipline that has driven GriTex into this new venture.

Griska is committed to reducing plastic waste, promoting circular economy practices, and transforming discarded plastics into reusable raw materials for manufacturing and constru

Science_Inputs:
The technical foundation of the solution is rooted in volumetric density science and upstream hydrological auditing through four pathways:

1. Logistics Science & Volumetric Density: The low bulk density of loose post-consumer PET bottles, which is around 0.03-0.04 g/cm³, poses significant logistical and economic challenges for developing a circular economy, especially for long-distance transport from inland urban centres like Masindi to primary-city factories. Mechanical shredding of the bottles into flakes at the source increases the bulk density to approximately 0.28-0.50 g/cm³, significantly reducing shipment volume and making transportation economically viable. This key technical and logistical step is essential in connecting inland waste sources with the global recycling market.

YC_OneLiner: VisionLoop Africa transforms PET bottles into sustainable packaging through collection and aggregation network, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 120 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | Computer vision sorting | Spectral analysis | IoT/Smart systems
Science_Inputs:
The core insight is "Optical Polymer Fingerprinting" via Deep Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Standard recycling relies on Near-Infrared (NIR) spectroscopy, which is cost-prohibitive for African SMEs. Our technical breakthrough is the use of Edge-AI—running complex computer vision models on low-power, local hardware—trained specifically on a "Global South Dataset."
While Western AI struggles with sun-degraded, deformed, or unbranded plastics common in African landfills, our model uses Transfer Learning to identify plastics based on structural morphology and "degradation signatures." This creates a systems-based shift from centralized sorting (expensive/rare) to decentralized sorting (affordable/ubiquitous), ensuring polymer purity at the first point of collection.
Bold_Characteristics:
VisionLoop challenges the assumption that "high-tech is incompatible with the informal sector." Most circularity solutions either stick to low-value manual labor or try to replace people with multi-million dollar automation.
This idea is bold because:
It Augments Human Intelligence: It turns an unskilled waste picker into a "Data-Verified Sorting Technician" using a $500 sensor rig.
It Challenges the Linear Value Chain: If it succeeds at scale, it turns every informal buy-back center in Africa into a certified purity-validation hub.
The Outcome: It shifts the power dynamic; waste pickers no lo

Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in the understanding that plastic bottle waste persists in the environment because it is lightweight, durable, and economically undervalued, not because it lacks material usefulness. Research and waste flow data show that PET plastic bottles retain structural integrity after single use, making them suitable for repeated non food applications without the need for energy intensive reprocessing.

From a systems perspective, the project addresses a key failure in the waste management chain: the absence of viable end markets for low value plastics at community level. By creating simple, desirable products such as pencil pouches and storage containers, the solution introduces a local demand signal that incentivizes collection and prevents plastic leakage into the environment.

The approach also draws on behavioral insights. When waste is visibly transformed into useful, everyday items, communities are more likely to segregate, collect, and value plastic waste. For st
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea is bold because it challenges the assumption that meaningful plastic waste solutions must rely on large scale, centralized recycling plants and complex technologies. Instead, it demonstrates that simple, human centered upcycling can absorb low value plastic waste and generate real economic and environmental value at community level.

The project also challenges the belief that plastic bottles are only suitable for disposal or downcycling into low quality materials. By converting them into durable, useful products like pencil pouches and storage containers, the solution repositions pl
Problem_Addressed:

Small scale recyclers often bypass plastic bottles due to low resale value, leaving this waste stream largely unmanaged.

YC_OneLiner: GreenZA transforms PET bottles into recycled pellets for manufacturing through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 500 tonnes annually
Target_Countries: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, South Africa, Zimbabwe
Science_Inputs:
The core insight behind our solution is that plastic recycling in many African regions fails not because of lack of waste, but due to the absence of localized processing and value-addition infrastructure. Most collected plastic is transported long distances to Gauteng or exported, increasing costs, emissions, and excluding local communities from value creation.

GreenZA addresses this gap by establishing pelletization as a regional hub for plastic recycling. Using science-based material sorting, washing, shredding, and pelletization processes, we convert post-consumer plastics into standardized, high-quality plastic pellets that meet industry requirements. This systems-based approach shortens the recycling value chain, improves material consistency, enables local manufacturing, and creates a reliable feedstock for downstream products. Supported by data systems, AI-enabled tracking, and technical oversight from scientists and environmentalists, the model transforms waste management from
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because GreenZA shifts plastic recycling from a low-value, transport-dependent activity into a high-value, localized circular industry. Instead of exporting or sending waste to distant hubs like Gauteng, we establish a regional pelletization hub that anchors the entire recycling ecosystem locally. It boldly integrates informal waste pickers into a formal, tech-enabled value chain, supported by scientists, environmentalists, and AI/IT specialists, turning waste into standardized industrial feedstock. By proving that plastic waste can be processed, commercialized, and scaled
Problem_Addressed: GreenZA is addressing the growing problem of unmanaged plastic waste that ends up in landfills, illegal dumping sites, rivers, and oceans. This results in environmental pollution, health risks to communities, loss of biodiversity, and missed economic opportunities. The lack of data, technology in
Beneficiaries: The communities that benefit most from GreenZA’s solution are villages, rural areas, and underprivileged urban neighborhoods that lack formal waste collection and management services. By integrating waste pickers and community members into our collection

Science_Inputs:
The core insight behind SakaTaka is that plastic waste is not primarily a materials problem but a systems and information problem. In many African cities, plastic is lost not because it cannot be recycled, but because collection systems lack visibility, coordination, and incentives across the value chain.

SakaTaka applies systems thinking and digital infrastructure to close this gap. By capturing data at the point of collection and linking households, collectors, and recyclers on a single platform, we create feedback loops that improve behavior, operational efficiency, and market reliability. Measured waste flows enable route optimization, fair payment, accountability, and predictable supply for recyclers.

Once plastic is tracked, measured, and valued, it becomes an economic input rather than environmental leakage. This systems-level shift is what makes scalable plastic recovery possible.
Bold_Characteristics:
SakaTaka challenges the assumption that Africa’s plastic waste problem must be solved through heavy infrastructure or centralized systems. Instead, it treats plastic recovery as a digital coordination challenge and builds infrastructure in software, not concrete.

The boldness lies in formalizing and scaling the informal. Rather than replacing existing waste collectors and community groups, SakaTaka turns them into data-enabled operators, giving visibility, incentives, and market access where none existed before. This unlocks recovery of plastics that are currently ignored because they are low
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste in East African cities is growing faster than the systems designed to manage it. Most plastic is low-value, poorly sorted at source, and collected through fragmented, informal operations that lack data, coordination, and reliable payment mechanisms. As a result, recyclable plastics are often mixed with general waste, dumped in open sites, burned, or washed into waterways, despite having reuse or recycling potential.

Beneficiaries: SakaTaka primarily benefits waste collection companies and community-based organizations in urban and coastal African communities by providing digital tools that improve efficiency, transparency, and income stability. The scientific and technical insight behind sustainable braiding hair is a transition from petroleum-based polymer engineering to biological materials science. The "bold idea" is treating the biology of a plant or a protein not as a substitute for plastic, but as a molecule that can be refined to mimic the mechanical and thermal properties of human keratin ie hair proteins follicles. 
The true "systems" innovation isn't just the hair itself, but the remapping of the supply chain. Decentralising the manufacturing as traditionally the hair is mass-produced in centralised Asian mega factories. The bio-based model is distributed as processing units are placed near banana plantations in East and West Africa. This creates a circular bio economy and supply chain, where agricultural waste (stems) becomes the feedstock for high-value beauty products.

The volume of waste is staggering because of the sheer quantity of hair used per person.

Scientifically, plastics such as PET, HDPE, and LDPE are durable polymers that retain material value long after use. If unmanaged, they break down into microplastics and release toxic additives that contaminate soil, water, and air. The core insight behind our solution is that plastic recycling performance improves dramatically when material flows are coordinated, measured, and upgraded at system level, rather than treated as isolated collection activities. Data from Recyc Works Industries shows that the same plastic waste increases in value, quality, and recyclability once it is aggregated at scale, processed into standardized formats, and sold through consistent offtake channels.
Technically, the solution applies material flow analysis to plastic streams (PET, HDPE, PP), optimizing the transition from loose waste to baled and processed feedstock. This reduces contamination, improves conversion rates, and lowers logistics costs per kilogram. Weight-based tracking and quality grading allow accurate measurement of volumes, yields, and losses, forming the basis for reliable monitoring and reporting.

YC_OneLiner: Individual  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through enzymatic breakdown, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 20 tonnes
Technologies: Enzymatic degradation | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | IoT/Smart systems
Science_Inputs: The core insight is that enzyme based plastic recycling fails to scale in Africa not because enzymes do not work, but because enzyme production is centralized, costly, and inaccessible. By using naturally occurring enzyme producing organisms, immobilized growth systems, and continuous extracellular enzyme harvesting, the system delivers functional enzyme cocktails without pharmaceutical level purification. This reduces cost, improves robustness, and allows deployment in decentralized urban settings using local materials and skills.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea challenges the assumption that advanced biotechnology for plastic circularity must be centralized, capital intensive, and limited to high income economies. If successful at scale, African cities and coastal communities could produce their own biological recycling tools, enabling safe treatment of plastics that are currently burned or dumped. This would fundamentally change how low value plastics are managed, shifting from disposal to biological recovery and circular reuse.
Problem_Addressed: Plastic waste in Africa is dominated by low value and mixed plastics such as films, multilayer packaging, contaminated PET, and flexible consumer plastics. In rapidly growing cities across Nigeria and other African countries, these materials are rarely recycled because they are unsuitable for mechanical recycling and have no safe local alternatives. As a result, they are burned, dumped in open landfills, or washed into drainage systems and waterways, contributing to flooding, public health risks
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries of this solution are urban communities, local municipalities, and informal waste workers who are most directly affected by plastic pollution.

PET bottles are durable, lightweight and water-resistant, making them ideal as reusable planting pots for vertical vegetable gardens. Cocopeat, produced from up-cycled coconut husks, retains moisture, improves aeration and supports healthy root growth; turning an agricultural waste stream into a high-value growing medium. Recycling bottles into planting pots filled with cocopeat diverts plastic from the environment, creates income opportunities, and greens public spaces.

At the systems level, the approach tackles two major local waste streams simultaneously, cutting leakage into mangroves and nearshore waters. A community-led collection and training model uses social norms, incentives and hands-on practice to drive participation and long-term adoption.

The novelty is the direct link between waste up-cycling and food production: a low-cost, appl
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea reframes plastic from a nuisance into a locally valuable resource that improves food security and livelihoods. Instead of relying on municipal systems or high-tech recycling, it uses low-cost, locally available materials (PET bottles & coconut husks) and community action to deliver immediate environmental and social benefits.

It challenges assumptions that waste must be centrally processed, that plastic solutions are separate from food security, and that community initiatives can’t reduce ocean leakage. By creating income and visible benefits, households are incentivized to collect
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic Waste Problem at Hindi and Mokowe, Lamu County – Kenya

Plastic waste in Hindi and Mokowe (Lamu County, Kenya) is a visible and growing environmental and socio-economic challenge. An estimated 60–70% of locally generated plastic waste remains uncollected, mainly from hotels, households, shops, markets and transport hubs. Due to the absence of a community-level collection system and limited county government capacity, plastic waste accumulates in streets, drains and informal dumping sites

Science_Inputs:

Alternative fiber technology: We convert agricultural waste (dry grass) into pulp suitable for making eco-bags and paper products, reducing reliance on trees and plastics.

Mechanical and chemical processing: Using pulping and drying machines, we efficiently transform raw fibers into durable, reusable products with consistent quality.

Resource efficiency: Low-energy production methods reduce water and energy consumption compared to conventional paper and plastic manufacturing.

Systems approach: By integrating raw material sourcing, production, distribution, and recycling, we create a closed-loop system that minimizes waste, ensures steady income for local farmers, and promotes sustainable consumption.
Bold_Characteristics:
EcoBagMart is bold because it tackles multiple urgent challenges simultaneously while creating measurable impact:

Environmental Impact: Reduces plastic pollution, promotes recycling, and has preserved 2 trees since operations began.

Community Empowerment: Provides steady income for local farmers, sourcing raw materials directly from them.

Job Creation: Employs local workers in production, operations, and security, building skills and livelihoods.

Science_Inputs: Our core insight is that plastic waste in Nigeria is not failing because of a lack of technology, but because ventures are not investment-ready within a complex system. Plastic recovery only scales when informal collection networks, market demand, finance, and policy incentives work together. Our toolkit applies a systems-based approach to diagnose where ventures break down—commercially, technically, or institutionally—and helps founders redesign their models so these elements align. This increases the likelihood that waste solutions can scale sustainably, rather than remaining small pilots.
Bold_Characteristics:

What makes this approach bolder is our plan to use AI to strengthen and scale our Investment Readiness Toolkit. AI allows us to analyse business models, unit economics, and risk gaps across many early-stage waste ventures, identify common failure points, and provide faster, more consistent, and more tailored support to founders.

YC_OneLiner: Afric Precious Plastic transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving local SMEs and entrepreneurs, targeting 15,000,000 tonnes annually
Target_Countries: Algeria, Angola, Burkina Faso, Kenya, Tanzania , Uganda
Science_Inputs:
Most recycling solutions continue to rely on large scale recycling infrastructure, which has many environmental, economic, and social challenges. China’s plastic ban showed Europe and the US that they cannot continue to rely on dumping their recyclables on developing countries. We take a different approach - keep material local through empowering people connected globally. 

The benefit of the AfricPrecious Plastic Universe is that as lessons are learned and new practices are developed in one part of the world, the rest of our community benefits through the open sharing of information. Under traditional circumstances, gained knowledge is utilized only by the organization that discovered it, which slows the pace of development and adoption around the world. Our model of open source technology and knowledge linked by an online community of practitioners is already providing a significant impact to the plastic waste problem globally.
Bold_Characteristics:
Three things make us innovative: open source, global online collaboration, and small-scale local recycling. We provide open-source machine designs, information, and products for free online, empowering others to build and sell machines and products themselves. This lets us focus on development and community support while local organizations handle the actual recycling.

Rather than sending a simple newsletter, we maintain an online platform and forums where the community can collaborate directly. This accelerates solutions because the plastic waste problem is too big for one organization to so
Problem_Addressed:

Science_Inputs:
Our solution combines material science, applied research, and behavioural systems design to address plastic waste. Scientifically, we transform post-consumer plastics into durable, high-quality interior and construction products, experimenting with polymer selection, blending, moulding, and surface finishing to achieve tiles, decking, and furniture with the smoothness, durability, and aesthetic appeal of conventional materials.

Technically, we conduct workshop-based prototyping and real-world testing, optimising product performance while ensuring local manufacturability.

Beyond materials, our research addresses the behavioural barrier in recycling: many people do not recycle because they do not see the tangible value of their efforts. By linking collection to products people can touch, use, and relate to, and by organising community-based collection franchises, we create a system that motivates participation, ensures reliable feedstock, and reinforces circular behaviour.

YC_OneLiner: Borlahub transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 18,000 tonnes annually
Technologies: Bio-based materials | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs:
BorlaHub is built on a combination of scientific, systems-based, and behavioral insights drawn from waste management research, field data, and real-world implementation in Ghana.

1. Source segregation is the highest-impact intervention
Research and field evidence consistently show that segregating waste at the point of disposal dramatically increases recycling rates and material value. BorlaHub applies this insight by prioritizing behavior change in schools, using color-coded bins and clear visual cues that align with proven behavioral science principles—simplicity, habit formation, and repeated exposure. Schools are ideal intervention points because routines are structured and behaviors can scale across generations.

2. Informal systems are central, not peripheral
Studies across African cities show that informal waste collectors recover the majority of recyclable plastics. Rather than replacing them, BorlaHub’s system is designed to digitally integrate informal collectors into a semi
Bold_Characteristics: BorlaHub is a bold idea because it challenges the assumption that effective waste management in Africa must rely on expensive, centralized infrastructure. Instead, it proves that value can be created at the source by empowering schools, communities, and informal waste collectors with the right behaviors, technology, and market access. At scale, waste shifts from a public burden to an economic asset, informal collectors become recognized entrepreneurs, recyclers gain reliable feedstock, and cities see reduced flooding, improved public health, and lasting environmental behavior change.
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic Waste Problem Addressed by BorlaHub

BorlaHub addresses the growing plastic waste crisis in urban and peri-urban communities in Ghana, with a strong focus on public schools and surrounding neighborhoods. Plastic waste particularly plastic bottles, single-use plastics, and plastic films (sachets and packaging) forms a significant portion of municipal solid waste but is poorly managed due to weak segregation systems, limited collection capacity, and fragmented recycling markets.

Science_Inputs:
The solution leverages systems-based and behavioral insights in plastic waste management. Research shows that source separation and community engagement increase recycling rates by over 50% in low-income urban settings (UNEP, 2022
). Small-scale mechanical recycling technologies allow PET bottles, HDPE, and other single-use plastics to be transformed into eco-bricks, paving blocks, and construction materials, creating a circular material flow. Material science demonstrates that mixed plastic blends, when processed correctly, can produce durable, low-cost building products. Additionally, behavioral studies indicate that incentivizing informal waste collectors and local households increases participation and reduces littering. By combining community-led collection, technical recycling, and value-added product creation, the model turns plastic from an environmental burden into a sustainable economic resource.

Instead, it positions communities—households, traders, youth, and women—as the primary drivers of a circular economy, turning waste into a valuable resource.

YC_OneLiner: Organisation transforms HDPE containers into sustainable packaging through bioplastic alternatives, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 28 tonnes
Technologies: Bio-based materials | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Target_Countries: Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Namibia, Zambia , Zimbabwe
Science_Inputs:
The insight behind our solution lies in Circular Bio-Economy Integration, specifically the transition from a "linear-take-make-waste" agricultural model to an Integrated Multi-Trophic System (IMTS).

1. Material Science Insight (Upcycling)
The technical core involves Thermal Compression and Polymer Blending. We use a systems-based approach to combine discarded HDPE/LDPE agricultural plastics (irrigation pipes) with organic fiber waste. The insight is that agricultural plastic waste, when processed at localized, low-heat extrusion points, retains high structural integrity for non-pressure applications, such as recycled pond liners. This reduces CAPEX for farmers while permanently sequestering plastic in long-term infrastructure.

2. Biological Systems Insight (Nutrient Cycling)

YC_OneLiner: ATIME SA transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through plastic credit verification, serving rural farming communities, targeting 43,200 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | Spectral analysis
Target_Countries: Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sudan, Togo
Science_Inputs:
1️⃣ Composition et principe

Le WPC (Wood-Plastic Composite) est un matériau hybride combinant :

Fibres de bois (déchets de bois locaux ou recyclés)

Polymères thermoplastiques (plastiques recyclés : sacs, bouteilles, emballages)

Additifs : stabilisants UV, agents anti-moisissures, agents liants

Principe : les fibres de bois apportent rigidité et structure, tandis que le plastique assure résistance à l’humidité, durabilité et imperméabilité.

2️⃣ Propriétés physiques et mécaniques

Résistance à la traction et à la flexion → comparable ou supérieure à certains bois tropicaux

Résistance à l’eau et à l’humidité → ne gonfle pas, ne pourrit pas

Résistance aux termites et champignons → grâce au plastique et aux additifs

Durabilité → 20 à 40 ans selon conditions d’usage

Poids optimisé → facilité de transport et d’assemblage

3️⃣ Avantages environnementaux

Valorisation des déchets plastiques et bois → réduit pollution et émissions liées à l’incinération

Séquestration carbone → le CO₂
Bold_Characteristics:
Transformation locale des déchets : ATIME prend des déchets plastiques et bois souvent ignorés ou brûlés et les transforme en produits durables, créant une industrie circulaire inédite en Afrique de l’Ouest.

Innovation produit : Les tables-bancs en kit et portes WPC combinent durabilité, modularité et recyclage, offrant une solution unique pour les écoles et bâtiments publics.

Impact multiple : ATIME agit à la fois sur le climat, l’éducation, l’emploi et la protection des forêts, un modèle rare qui intègre écologie et social.

Scalabilité : La technologie peut être répliquée dans d’autres pa
Problem_Addressed:
fi plastique ciblé par ATIME

En Afrique de l’Ouest, les déchets plastiques ménagers et industriels constituent un problème majeur :

Sacs plastiques, bouteilles PET, emballages et films plastiques représentent la majorité des déchets.

La plupart sont jetés dans les rues, rivières ou décharges à ciel ouvert, ou brûlés, libérant CO₂ et autres polluants.

Le taux de recyclage est très faible, souvent inférieur à 10 % dans les grandes villes comme Lomé, Accra ou Cotonou.

Flux et acteurs

Collecte
Beneficiaries:
ommunautés scolaires

Écoles rurales et urbaines à faibles ressources

Élèves : meilleure assise, confort, concentration et sensibilisation à l’écologie grâce aux tables-bancs en kit

Collectivités et institutions publiques

Bâtiments publics et logements sociaux équipés de portes durables et sécurisées

Réduction des coûts liés aux remplacements fréquents et entretien

Environnement et climat

Ré

Description:
ATIME transforme des déchets plastiques et bois locaux en tables-bancs scolaires démontables et portes durables en bois composite (WPC).

Les tables-bancs en kit sont faciles à transporter et assembler, idéales pour les écoles rurales.

Les portes durables remplacent le bois traditionnel, résistant à l’eau, aux termites et à l’usure.

Chaque produit recycle des déchets, stocke du CO₂ et contribue à la protection des forêts.

Les enfants sont sensibilisés à l’écologie et à l’écoresponsabilité dès

My solution leverages several scientific and technical insights:
Material Science: The process involves understanding the properties of different plastics (e.g., PET, HDPE, PP) and their potential applications. For example, PET can be recycled into polyester fibers, while HDPE is suitable for construction materials.
Behavioral Insight: Encouraging community participation in plastic collection and sorting requires understanding social norms, incentives, and education. Gamification and rewards can motivate individuals to contribute.
Systems Thinking: The solution involves designing a circular economy system where plastic waste is continuously cycled back into production, reducing waste and promoting sustainability.
Technology: Utilizing decentralized, low-cost recycling technologies (e.g., shredding, melting, and molding) makes the process accessible and scalable in Nigeria.

Science_Inputs: The core insight is that plastic circularity fails not because of lack of waste, but due to poor value capture and weak aggregation systems. Flexible plastics are often rejected because they are highly contaminated and difficult to sort. Our approach uses data-driven sorting standards, community incentives, and low-cost processing methods to produce consistent, market-ready material. We will use behavioral insights (reward systems, community champions) to increase participation and reduce contamination. This creates a traceable supply chain, enabling buyers to trust the quality and consistency of recovered plastics.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea challenges the assumption that flexible plastics cannot be economically recycled in Africa. We believe the main barrier is not the material itself but the lack of systems that ensure quality, traceability, and stable demand. If successful, this model would transform flexible plastics from “waste” into a profitable resource, enabling coastal communities to scale circular solutions across Africa.
Problem_Addressed:
Coastal and urban communities in Kenya’s coastal region, particularly Mombasa and surrounding areas, are facing a rapidly growing plastic waste crisis dominated by low-value, single-use plastics such as sachets, thin packaging films, food wrappers, and mixed plastics from markets, households, and informal food supply chains. These plastics are largely non-recyclable within existing systems, resulting in leakage into drainage systems, beaches, mangroves, and the Indian Ocean.

Beneficiaries:

Science_Inputs:
Research Evidence for School Recycling Incentives (South Africa)
1. The "Incentive Necessity" Gap

Finding: A study at the University of Venda investigated student participation in waste management. It found that 41.3% of students identified "Economic Incentives" as the primary driver required for them to begin separating waste at the source.

Source: University of Venda Research Repository / Frontiers in Sustainability (2024)

2. The Educational Awareness vs. Action Gap (Umlazi, KZN)

Finding: Research in the Umlazi District (2022) found that while secondary school learners have "acute awareness" that pollution is harmful, they have "minimal awareness of effective practices" (like sorting and weighing).

Source: UNISA Institutional Repository (Mzobe, 2022) – "Perceptions of teachers and learners on solid waste management in Umlazi District schools."

3. The "Waste-to-Value" Economic Impact

Venture_Name: Burundian Association For Development, Democracy and Human Rights "AB3D"
YC_OneLiner: Burundian Association For Development, Democracy and Human Rights "AB3D" transforms PET bottles into verified plastic credits through plastic credit verification, serving waste collectors and infor...
Technologies: Bio-based materials | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
PLAST–LIFE is based on behavioural and systems insights rather than high-tech solutions. Research shows that informal plastic collection fails when people see no value in waste. By creating Life Credits, we turn plastic into a tangible resource, motivating households to sort and collect.
The system applies circular economy principles at micro-community level: waste is sorted at source, reused, or sold to recyclers, keeping plastic in circulation. Local, low-tech tracking (SMS/WhatsApp) ensures accountability without requiring complex infrastructure.
The innovation is human-centred design: aligning incentives, local capacities, and environmental benefit, making circular plastic systems practical, scalable, and community-owned.
Bold_Characteristics:
PLAST–LIFE challenges the assumption that plastic waste must be managed by big infrastructure or technology. Instead, it puts communities at the center, making plastic a resource, not a problem.
If it succeeds at scale:
•	households will actively collect and sort plastic because it has real value,
•	informal waste systems become functional and sustainable,
•	ecosystems, rivers, and soils see significant improvement,
•	youth and women gain income and agency, and
•	Africa’s plastic challenge shifts from a top-down problem to a community-driven solution.
The boldness lies in trusting local people
Problem_Addressed:
In Burundi, especially in Bujumbura and surrounding peri-urban areas, plastic pollution is everywhere. Single-use plastics; bags, bottles, sachets; are thrown on streets, rivers, and wetlands. Most households have no access to formal waste collection, and informal dumps are overflowing. Burning plastic is common, releasing toxic smoke.
The waste stream we target is household and small-business plastics; mostly PET bottles, sachets, and thin films; that are reusable or recyclable but currently lo

•	Households in urban and peri-urban neighborhoods
•	Informal recyclers and micro-transformation actors
•	Local communities affected by pollution and flooding
•	Ecosystems (wetlands, rivers, lake shores) that receive less plastic waste

Venture_Name: PLASTI-SENSE AFRICA – AI-Enabled Plastic Waste Mapping & Forecasting Platform
YC_OneLiner: PLASTI-SENSE AFRICA – AI-Enabled Plastic Waste Mapping & Forecasting Platform transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and inform...
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | IoT/Smart systems
Science_Inputs:
PLASTI-SENSE AFRICA leverages systems thinking and data-driven intelligence to address plastic leakage at its source. It integrates heterogeneous datasets that is geotagged community collection logs, satellite and drone imagery, urban activity indicators, and hydrological/weather patterns into an AI powered predictive model that forecasts plastic accumulation and leakage hotspots.

By combining predictive analytics, geospatial mapping, and early-warning algorithms, the platform enables proactive interventions rather than reactive cleanups. The inclusion of informal waste collectors as real-time data contributors ensures that local behaviors and flows are embedded into the system, making predictions more accurate and socially inclusive.

This approach transforms fragmented plastic waste management into a cohesive, intelligence driven circular system, providing actionable insights for municipalities, recyclers, and NGOs, while enabling measurable environmental and social impact.
Bold_Characteristics:
PLASTI-SENSE AFRICA is bold because it transforms plastic management from reactive cleanup to predictive, intelligence driven action, a leap beyond existing solutions in Africa. It combines AI, geospatial analytics, weather modeling, and community sourced data to forecast plastic leakage, identify hotspots, and trigger early interventions.

Unlike traditional recycling projects, it integrates informal waste collectors as active sensors, formalizing their role in the circular economy while generating measurable social and environmental impact. Its scalable, multi city design enables pan African

Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in a systems-based and behavioural insight that recognizes plastic pollution not only as a waste problem, but as a failure of local waste ecosystems—from consumption to disposal and recovery.

Core Insight

Plastic waste persists in African urban and coastal communities because collection systems, incentives, and behaviour change are disconnected. Most interventions focus on clean-ups or bans, but fail to create circular micro-systems that retain plastic value at community level.

Evidence & Research Basis

Studies show that over 80% of plastic leakage into oceans originates from land-based sources, particularly poorly managed urban waste systems.

Behavioural research indicates that people change disposal habits when waste has visible value (economic or social).

Community-based waste recovery models in low-income contexts perform better when youth leadership, incentives, and local reuse pathways are integrated.
Bold_Characteristics:

Large-scale,

Capital-intensive,

Led by municipalities or private companies.

The Assumption It Challenges

“Low-income urban and coastal communities are passive victims of plastic pollution, not capable of managing waste systems.”

Plastic waste shifts from being a public burden to a community asset;

Youth move from being seen as “beneficiaries” to environmental system leaders;

Cities reduce flooding, health risks, a

YC_OneLiner: Green Voyage transforms PET bottles into verified plastic credits through plastic credit verification, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 5,000 tonnes annually
Target_Countries: Kenya, South Africa, Tanzania , Uganda , Zambia
Science_Inputs: The core insight behind our solution is that plastic pollution is a systems failure rather than a purely technical one. Significant environmental harm occurs not because plastic cannot be managed, but because low value plastic streams lack economic incentives for recovery. Our approach applies the scientific and technical rigor of carbon markets to plastic waste by defining baselines of mismanaged plastic, quantifying additional recovery, and using digital monitoring, reporting, and verification systems to ensure traceability. By converting avoided leakage and safe treatment into verified outcomes, we create a feedback loop where environmental performance directly drives financial viability and long term system change.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it treats plastic pollution not as a cleanup activity, but as a verifiable environmental outcome that can be financed at scale. Our projects go beyond business as usual by establishing strict additionality, proving that the plastic recovered would not have been collected or safely treated without plastic credit revenue. By applying carbon market grade baselines, monitoring, and third party verification to plastic waste, we challenge the assumption that low value plastics are economically unviable. This approach directly links finance to real world impact, mobilizes

Science_Inputs:
AfriVision Circularity Labs leverages behavioural science and systems thinking to reduce plastic leakage at the source. Research shows that plastic sorting and collection improve significantly when communities are educated, incentivized, and supported with structured systems. By combining STEM-based curriculum, digital tracking, and community action labs, our approach links knowledge, behaviour, and measurable outcomes.

This hybrid system allows schools and youth hubs to quantify plastic collected, improve recycling feedstock quality, and generate micro-enterprises, creating a replicable, data-driven model. Unlike traditional downstream interventions, ACL integrates education, community engagement, and circular economy systems, producing both environmental and socio-economic impact.
Bold_Characteristics:
AfriVision Circularity Labs challenges the assumption that plastic waste solutions must start with recycling facilities or downstream clean-ups. Instead, it targets source-level behaviour change through education and community engagement, integrating schools, youth, and local hubs into circular economy systems.

If successful at scale, this approach would transform African cities’ plastic value chains, creating a generation of environmentally literate youth, measurable reductions in plastic leakage, new green jobs, and replicable, scalable models for communities across the continent. By linkin

These plastics dominate household and school waste streams but are rarely sorted at source, leading to low recycling rates and widespread leakage into drainage systems, waterways, and informal dumpsites.

Science_Inputs:
Gold Coast Tokota's solution is grounded in a systems understanding of how ocean bound waste move through urban and coastal environments, who interacts with them, and how value can be created before they enter the marine ecosystem. The technical insight is that multi-layer water sachet plastics, considered low-value in traditional recycling markets, can be safely processed and repurposed into durable footwear components with the right cleaning, shredding and lamination techniques.

Scientifically, our approach treats ocean bound plastics as a feedstock rather than a waste burden. By mapping waste streams from consumption to drainage and coastline points, we intervene upstream where collection is cheapest and where leakage reduction has the greatest environmental return. YC_OneLiner: So Pure Company Limited transforms PET bottles into eco-bricks and pavers through construction material production, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 300 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs:
The key insight is that plastic waste is not a “cleanup problem” — it’s a systems and market failure. Plastics leak into the environment mainly because there’s no reliable collection incentive, no consistent sorting, and no guaranteed buyer demand for the recovered material.

Our solution fixes this by creating a closed-loop system:

Demand-pull: We recycle plastics into raw material that can feed directly into manufacturing (films/packaging), so there is always a buyer for recovered waste.

Aggregation at scale: We organize collectors and aggregators so sachet film and flexible plastics (normally ignored) become economically viable to recover.

Process engineering: We apply proven recycling steps—sorting, washing, drying, shredding, and extrusion/pelletizing—to convert low-value waste into standardized, reusable material.

Feedback control: By tracking volumes, yields, contamination rates, and cost per kg collected, we continuously optimize the system for efficiency and profitability.
Bold_Characteristics:
This is a bold idea because we are not treating plastic waste as a charity clean-up activity—we are redesigning it into a profitable industrial system that can scale across an entire country.

Instead of relying on weak municipal collection or donor-funded projects, we are building a closed-loop circular economy where plastic waste becomes a permanent input for manufacturing. That means even the hardest and most ignored waste stream in Africa—sachet film and flexible plastics—can be collected, processed, and converted into valuable raw material.

It’s bold because it tackles three hard problem
Problem_Addressed:

Blocked drainage → flooding and sanitation risks

Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on a systems-based and material-use insight: plastic pollution persists in low-resource settings because alternatives are expensive, centralized, and disconnected from local production and behavior. Our approach redesigns the packaging system by shifting from imported, single-use plastic to locally produced, biodegradable materials made from recycled paper and waste streams already available in the community.

From a technical and material perspective, we use low-tech, manual production processes to convert recycled paper into durable packaging products and organic waste into charcoal briquettes. This reduces reliance on plastic and virgin materials while keeping production affordable and accessible in settings without advanced infrastructure.

From a systems and behavioral insight, local businesses continue using plastic because it is the only reliable option available. By producing alternatives locally, close to users, we remove cost, transport, and access barri
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it challenges the assumption that plastic waste solutions in Africa must be centralized, high-tech, or capital-intensive. YC_OneLiner: ReCircuMed transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through microbial processing, serving underserved communities, processing 30 tonnes
Technologies: Microbial processing | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems
Science_Inputs:
Pharmaceutical plastics are excluded from recycling not because the polymers are unsuitable, but because existing systems cannot safely manage chemical and biological contamination. HDPE, PET, and PP used in healthcare retain trace active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) and microbial residues that pose regulatory and public-health risks, even when present at low levels.
ReCircuMed applies principles from pharmaceutical quality assurance, analytical chemistry, and biosafety to address this bottleneck. By combining controlled aqueous treatment, targeted residue neutralisation, and validated microbial decontamination, the system removes contaminants while preserving polymer integrity. This allows plastics to meet safety thresholds required for downstream mechanical recycling.
At a systems level, the solution bridges healthcare waste management and plastic recycling, two sectors that currently operate in isolation. By introducing a validated decontamination step, ReCircuMed unlocks a hig
Bold_Characteristics:
ReCircuMed tackles one of the most difficult and neglected plastic waste streams—pharmaceutical and healthcare plastics—that most recycling systems deliberately avoid. Rather than focusing on low-risk household plastics, the solution confronts the regulatory, chemical, and biosafety barriers that have kept these materials locked out of the circular economy.
The boldness lies in applying pharmaceutical-grade quality assurance, contamination analysis, and validation methods to plastic recycling. By treating pharmaceutical plastics with the same rigor used in medicine safety, ReCircuMed challenge
Problem_Addressed: Africa’s healthcare and pharmaceutical sectors produce large volumes of plastic waste yearly, including high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polyethylene terephthalate (PET), and polypropylene (PP) from medicine bottles, blister packs, IV containers, syringes, and laboratory disposables. YC_OneLiner: KOLIBA.ngo transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through plastic credit verification, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 2,500 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Packaging alternatives | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs:
Behavioural Economics & Decentralised Systems Theory.

1. Behavioural Insight (Immediate Gratification over Altruism): Our approach uses Hyperbolic Discounting principles. Environmental benefit is a "distant" reward that rarely drives daily behaviour in low-income settings. KOLIBA converts recycling into an immediate tangible gain (K-Points = Airtime/Cash). By gamifying the process (e.g., "Golden Bottle" random rewards), we trigger variable reward schedules—the same psychological mechanism that makes social media addictive—but repurposed for segregating waste. We don't ask people to "save the planet"; we ask them to "win a prize," which achieves the environmental outcome as a byproduct.

2. Systems-Based Insight (Thermodynamic Efficiency of Decentralisation): Traditional waste management tries to impose a centralised grid (large trucks, fixed routes) on a chaotic, organic city structure. This is energy-inefficient. KOLIBA leverages Swarm Intelligence. Instead of routing one expensive t
Bold_Characteristics:
KOLIBA is driving a paradigm shift from "Waste Management" to Resource Mining. 

Unlike traditional models that try to replace informal pickers with municipal trucks, KOLIBA challenges the assumption that formalisation requires replacement. Instead, they prove you can formalise the transaction while empowering the existing workforce. They reject the idea that high-tech solutions are unsuitable for low-literacy users, viewing the informal sector as a distributed workforce to be unleashed rather than a problem to be solved.

At scale, this model decouples waste recovery from heavy infrastructure
Problem_Addressed:
We aim to provide a solution to the "First Mile" market failure in urban Africa.
We operate in rapidly urbanising Sub-Saharan African cities, specifically targeting high-density peri-urban neighbourhoods and coastal zones where municipal waste collection is intermittent or non-existent (<40% coverage).
Our primary focus is Post-Consumer Rigid Plastics (PET, HDPE, PP). These high-value materials are currently lost because they are co-mingled with wet organic waste at the household level, renderin
Beneficiaries:
KOLIBA focuses on those at the "bottom of the pyramid," transforming the lives of the informal sector and small businesses:

1. Informal Waste Workers: No longer exploited by middlemen, these "invisible" workers gain transparent pricing, digital payment histories, and the creditworthiness needed to build a future with dignity.

2. SMEs (Aggregators): Small depot owners receive the "Missing Middle"

YC_OneLiner: Engee Ecodesigns  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving women and youth entrepreneurs, processing 12 tonnes
Science_Inputs: Our solution combines engineering, material science, and circular economy practices to address plastic waste. Plastics are collected, cleaned, and processed using polymer upcycling techniques, then integrated into fashion and lifestyle products. This method reduces environmental pollution while creating income opportunities and skills for displaced populations, women, and youth. By applying systems thinking, we link waste recovery, technical processing, and social impact, creating a scalable and replicable model that transforms plastic waste into value and promotes inclusive, sustainable development in Africa.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it reimagines plastic waste as a valuable resource rather than an environmental problem. At Engee Ecodesigns, we apply chemical engineering-based upcycling techniques to convert plastics into sustainable fashion and lifestyle products, creating durable, market-ready items. The approach is systems-driven, linking waste reduction, skill-building, entrepreneurship, and income generation for displaced populations, women, and youth. By combining creative design, circular economy principles, and community engagement, the model is replicable, scalable, and transformative,
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste is a major environmental challenge across Africa. In Nigeria and other communities, single-use plastics, packaging materials, and discarded bottles accumulate in streets, waterways, and landfills, causing pollution, blocking drainage systems, and harming wildlife. Limited collection and recycling infrastructure leads to contamination of land and water, contributing to climate change and threatening human health, particularly in vulnerable and displaced communities.
Engee Ecodesigns
Beneficiaries: Our solution most benefits displaced populations, women, and youth living in underserved communities. By engaging them in plastic upcycling, production, and entrepreneurship, the solution creates income, builds skills, and improves long-term economic resilience. Communities also benefit from reduced plastic pollution and improved environmental conditions.

Venture_Name: Blue Earth Lab (originating from Africa Blue Food Festival)
YC_OneLiner: Blue Earth Lab (originating from Africa Blue Food Festival) transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through collection and aggregation network, serving waste collectors and informal workers,...
Science_Inputs:
Our core insight is that plastic leakage in Africa is a systems failure, not an infrastructure gap. 

Research and field data show that most plastic enters the environment through informal food and coastal economies where incentives for recovery are weak. By embedding circularity into these systems; using behavioral incentives, value-chain integration, and measurable diversion metrics, we align environmental outcomes with economic participation enabling recovery of plastics typically considered “non-recyclable” in informal contexts.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea challenges the assumption that plastic circularity must start with centralized recycling infrastructure or consumer behavior change alone. We demonstrate that market-ready circularity can be built directly inside informal food and coastal economies. If successful at scale, plastic recovery becomes a viable livelihood and service economy, food systems become plastic-accountable, and coastal communities shift from pollution hotspots to circular economy hubs across Africa.
Problem_Addressed:
Blue Earth Lab addresses plastic leakage from coastal and inland urban food systems in East Africa, with initial focus on Tanzania, Uganda, and Kenya. Key waste streams originate from fish markets, informal food vendors, festivals, and coastal tourism, and include single-use sachets, PET bottles, food packaging films, takeaway containers, and mixed low-value plastics with limited recycling value.

These plastics leak into coastal waters, beaches, drainage systems, and informal dumpsites, directl
Beneficiaries:
Informal waste workers and community collectors

Coastal fishing and market communities

Youth and women-led groups engaged in recovery and sorting

Small food vendors and SMEs operating in plastic-intensive environments

Municipalities and coastal authorities through reduced leakage and cleaner public spaces

The model combines source-segregated collection, community-led recovery, and conversion of low-value plastics into reusable assets and products, supported by data tracking and viable revenue streams.

The solution is based on a scientific and systemic approach to the circular economy of plastics, which considers plastic waste not as a residue, but as a secondary resource that can be valorized locally. It relies on the principle of material circularity, aiming to keep plastic in a prolonged use cycle through collection, sorting, processing, and reuse.

From a technical standpoint, the project uses low-energy mechanical recycling processes, adapted to resource-limited contexts. These technologies make it possible to transform post-consumer plastics into durable and resistant products (paving stones, furniture, equipment), thus reducing the volume of waste and the pressure on natural resources.

From a systemic perspective, the solution integrates the entire local value chain – waste producers, collectors, processors, and end users – while combining technological innovation, community organization, and economic incentives. This holistic approach makes it possible to generate a measurab
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea is bold because it challenges the assumption that plastic circularity solutions must be expensive, highly industrialized, and concentrated in large cities to be effective. The project demonstrates that a decentralized, community-based, and low-tech model can transform plastic waste into useful resources, even in a fragile Sahelian context like that of Timbuktu.

The initiative also challenges the notion that local communities are merely passive beneficiaries. On the contrary, it positions them as central actors in the collection, processing, and economic valorization of plastic, crea

Mali is facing increasing plastic pollution, particularly visible in urban and riverside areas like Timbuktu. Plastic bags, bottles, and single-use packaging are accumulating in the environment due to inadequate waste management, a lack of collection and recycling infrastructure, and a lack of appropriate technologies. Although a 2012 law banning non-biodegradable plastic bags exists, its enforcement remains limited.

This situation leads to serious environmental impacts, including the degradati
Beneficiaries: The main beneficiaries are young people and women in urban communities, informal waste collectors, local municipalities, schools, and all the inhabitants of Timbuktu who benefit from a healthier environment, local economic opportunities and a sustainable improvement in living conditions.

YC_OneLiner: Pakam technology Limited transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 624 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: Pakam combines behavioral science, data-driven aggregation, and digital technology to optimize plastic recovery. Behavioral insights drive household participation, material classification standards improve recyclability, and real-time digital tracking ensures traceable transactions and reliable feedstock. EV-based logistics and integrated microfinance create a systems-level solution that connects informal collectors to markets efficiently, enabling measurable impact and scalable circularity.
Bold_Characteristics: Pakam challenges the assumption that informal waste collection cannot be formalized or profitable. By combining digital marketplaces, EV logistics, and access to finance, it transforms fragmented collection into a traceable, scalable circular system. At scale, it will create predictable incomes for collectors, reliable supply for recyclers, and measurable reductions in plastic leakage, demonstrating that profitable, inclusive circular economies are possible in African cities.
Problem_Addressed: Plastic leakage in African cities is driven by weak source separation fragmented informal collection and limited access to quality recycling markets. This results in plastic pollution in drains waterways and communities while informal collectors remain excluded from stable income and value chains.
Beneficiaries: Primary beneficiaries are informal waste collectors and low income urban communities. Secondary beneficiaries include recycling companies municipalities and FMCG partners seeking scalable and traceable plastic recovery solutions.

YC_OneLiner: WasteVest Technologies Limited  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 12,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs:
WasteVest is informed by systems-level research and firsthand ecosystem exposure. Insights from the documentary *Lagos: Plastic and the Fight to Recycle* highlighted how informal collectors sustain Nigeria’s recycling economy despite weak coordination and infrastructure. Further learning from the Lagos Business School Sustainability Centre deepened our understanding of extended producer responsibility, behavioural incentives, and the gaps between policy and on-ground execution.

Research and engagements through the Food and Beverage Alliance revealed how PET bottle pricing fluctuates based on demand, aggregation efficiency, and logistics, rather than supply alone. We observed that value leakage occurs not at recycling plants, but at the coordination layer between households, collectors, and aggregators.

WasteVest applies this insight by using simple digital tools to improve traceability, demand aggregation, payment flow, and behavioural participation, strengthening existing systems ra
Bold_Characteristics:
WasteVest is bold because it challenges the assumption that effective waste management requires heavy infrastructure or owning trucks and recycling plants. Instead, it proves that the real bottleneck is coordination, traceability, and incentives across households, collectors, and recyclers.

When WasteVest succeeds at scale, plastic waste will be reliably collected and recycled, informal and formal actors will earn more predictable income, and urban communities will see cleaner, safer environments. It could transform Nigeria’s recycling ecosystem into a coordinated, data-driven, and economical

Our solution is grounded in behavioral science, systems design, and circular economy principles.

Scientifically, research shows that people are more likely to adopt sustainable habits when they are easy, visible, and emotionally rewarding. Single-use plastic persists in tourism because convenience outweighs intention. Our stainless-steel bottle removes this friction by providing a safe, reusable alternative that fits seamlessly into a traveler’s daily routine.
Bold_Characteristics:
This is a bold idea because it reimagines tourism itself as a tool for environmental action, not a source of pollution.

Instead of relying on regulations, cleanup campaigns, or complex recycling systems, our solution boldly targets the root cause of plastic waste in tourism: traveler behavior. We transform a simple object a water bottle into a behavior-change system, a storytelling platform, and a sustainability badge that travelers proudly carry across destinations.
Problem_Addressed: Tourism is a major but often overlooked contributor to plastic pollution. Travelers routinely rely on single-use plastics especially disposable water bottles, food packaging, toiletry containers, and souvenir wraps due to convenience, limited access to safe refill options, and lack of awareness while on the move. Science_Inputs:
The scientific and systems-based insight behind Mckingtorch Africa’s recycled plastic solutions (specifically their boards used for school desks and bus shelters) lies in the material science of thermoplasts and the integration of circular economy principles into urban infrastructure.

Founded by Makafui Awuku, the venture moves beyond simple "upcycling" (art) into industrial-grade recycling (functional materials).

1. Scientific Insight: Polymer Consolidation

The core technical process involves the thermal transformation of Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE) and High-Density Polyethylene (HDPE).

    The Raw Material: They focus heavily on "pure water" sachets (LDPE) and plastic bottles (HDPE/PET). These polymers are durable, water-resistant, and non-biodegradable, which makes them a nuisance in nature but an asset in construction.

    The Process: The plastic is cleaned, shredded, and then subjected to heat and pressure (compression molding). Unlike wood, which rots, or metal, which r
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea as it has created the most sustainable solution for plastic recycling which is energy efficient, smokeless and the boards can last for hundreds of years. It can also be easily replicated across the continent in countries with similar plastic waste and developmental problems. The model is creating the most sustainable jobs in the sector and the most sustainable solutions from the waste which is also capturing and storing away carbon.
Problem_Addressed: Ghana generates approximately 1.1 million metric tonnes of plastic waste every year. The country is a net importer of raw plastics. About 2.58 million metric tonnes of raw plastics are imported annually, with roughly 73% eventually ending up as waste. The "Sachet" Phenomenon: A unique driver in Ghana is the reliance on sachet water (500ml plastic pouches). While essential for providing affordable drinking water, these sachets constitute a massive portion of the litter found in urban drains and c
Beneficiaries: informal sector waste pickers, children, coastal communities, youth

Science_Inputs: Our solution is based on material science and recycling technology. Plastic waste, primarily PET and other polymers, can be processed and converted into high-quality polyester fibers through mechanical and chemical recycling techniques. By optimizing the cleaning, shredding, and fiber-extrusion processes, we produce fibers that meet textile industry standards. The insight lies in recognizing that local plastic waste is a valuable, underutilized resource and that with the right processing technology, it can replace imported fibers reducing environmental impact and strengthening Ethiopia’s domestic supply chain.
Bold_Characteristics: Our idea challenges the assumption that Ethiopia must rely on imported polyester fibers for the textile industry. By converting local plastic waste into high-quality fibers, we create a homegrown, circular solution that reduces pollution, cuts import costs, and strengthens local manufacturing. We are the first to implement this in our country and in east Africa, and we aim to expand across East Africa. If scaled successfully, this approach could transform plastic waste into a valuable industrial resource, inspire other countries to adopt similar solutions, and set a new standard for sustainabl
Problem_Addressed:
Ethiopia generates an estimated 600,000–700,000 tons of plastic waste annually, yet less than 10% is recycled, with most waste ending up in open dumps, waterways, or burned. Post-consumer PET plastic is one of the fastest-growing and least managed waste streams nationwide.

This creates serious environmental and economic impacts. Municipalities face rising waste management costs, waste collectors earn low incomes due to limited value-added recycling, and communities suffer from pollution, floodi
Beneficiaries: Our solution benefits multiple groups, with the greatest impact on local communities, small textile manufacturers, and the environment. Communities in Tigray gain cleaner neighborhoods and safer waterways as plastic waste is removed. Local textile businesses benefit from a reliable, locally produced supply of polyester fibers, reducing reliance on imports. Additionally, Ethiopia as a country benef

The growth in international Visitors from 51,126 in 2023 to 2,199,820 in 2025 represents a remarkable resurgence in interest, reinforcing Victoria falls’ reputation as a world class attraction, But Livingstone city still Experience Unsustainable disposal methods of Plastic waste from households, marketplaces, and industrial sources despite it being the World Class Tourist Destination.

Livingstone City produces around 90tpd of disposable waste. Around 50% of this is collected from the CBD and public spaces like markets. Up to 5% is collected from single-user facilities run privately by high waste institutions like the hotels. The rest of the waste – approximately 41tpd – is in the townships where the collection rate varies depending on success of the contracted waste collection

YC_OneLiner: Plastivie  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 12,000 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs:
PlastiVie is built on a circular economy and systems-thinking approach to plastic waste management, combining environmental science, low-cost recycling technology, and community-based collection systems.

From a scientific and technical perspective, the solution is based on:
	•	The categorization of plastics by polymer type (PET, HDPE, LDPE, PP), which allows safe and efficient sorting and recycling.
	•	Mechanical recycling processes (sorting, washing, shredding, melting, and molding) that transform plastic waste into reusable raw materials and finished products such as paving tiles, construction materials, and everyday utility items.
	•	The use of low-energy, decentralized recycling equipment, suitable for local contexts like Rufisque, which reduces transportation emissions and operational costs.
Problem_Addressed: PlastiVie tackles the major problem of plastic pollution in Senegal, particularly in Rufisque, where plastic waste threatens the environment and public health. The project aims to collect this waste and transform it into reusable and eco-friendly items, such as paving stones, benches, and decorative objects. In a global context where plastic production continues to increase, PlastiVie helps reduce environmental impact, valorize waste, and promote a sustainable local circular economy.
Beneficiaries:
The primary beneficiaries of PlastiVie are coastal and urban communities in Rufisque, Senegal, particularly youth, women, and low-income households who rely on informal waste collection for income. Local residents benefit from a cleaner environment, reduced plastic pollution, and improved public health.
	•	Community-based waste collectors and recycling workers gain access to stable, sustainable li

YC_OneLiner: ecoWealth Solutions transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving coastal fishing communities, processing 15 tonnes
Technologies: Bio-based materials | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems
Science_Inputs:
EcoWealth Solutions is built on the insight that plastic waste is not just an environmental failure, but a systems failure in how value is recognized and distributed. Across Africa, large volumes of plastic waste exist alongside widespread underemployment and income insecurity. The core problem is not the absence of materials, but the absence of simple, accessible systems that enable individuals and microenterprises to convert waste into economic value.
Our solution applies a practical systems-based approach: we break down waste-to-value processes into clear, low-cost, replicable steps that individuals can adopt without advanced technology or capital. By combining environmental education, basic process frameworks, and market-oriented thinking, EcoWealth Solutions enables people to treat plastic waste as a resource rather than a liability.
The model reduces plastic leakage into the environment while improving livelihoods by aligning environmental outcomes with direct economic incentives
Bold_Characteristics: EcoWealth Solutions is a bold response to Africa’s plastic waste crisis because it reframes plastic not as waste, but as a distributed economic resource. Instead of relying on centralized recycling infrastructure, which remains limited and slow, we empower individuals and microenterprises to convert plastic waste into income through practical, low-cost, and scalable methods. The innovation lies in combining environmental education, micro-enterprise thinking, and accessible tools to unlock value at the grassroots level. This approach tackles plastic pollution at its source while simultaneously
Problem_Addressed: Plastic waste is increasing rapidly due to poor waste management, low recycling awareness, and limited income opportunities for people handling waste. In many communities, plastics clog drainage systems, pollute land and water, and create health and environmental risks. At the same time, many microenterprises and individuals lack access to affordable knowledge and tools to turn plastic waste into income. EcoWealth Solutions addresses this gap by turning plastic waste from an environmental proble
Beneficiaries: Microenterprises, small scale recyclers, and local communities in coastal and urban areas benefit most from our solution. They gain access to income generating opportunities from collecting, sorting, and repurposing plastic waste, while also improving local environmental conditions and promoting sustainable practices.
Team_Info: EcoWealth Solutions is currently led by the founder, Kings Ene, who brings experience in sustainability education, publishing, and financial literacy. The team leverages partnerships with freelancers and collaborators for design, marketing, and technical support.
Description: EcoWealth Solutions provides practical education and guides that teach individuals and microenterprises how to convert plastic waste into income-generating opportunities. Through simple, affordable methods, we help people turn environmental waste into economic value while promoting sustainability.

Specifically, we process two categories of plastic waste: multi-layer plastics (MLP), which consist of one or more layers of plastic and/or aluminum foil, and mixed plastic waste that cannot be efficiently segregated. Of the approximately 6 billion tonnes of plastic waste generated globally, around 14% comprises MLP. These materials typically end up in landfills, are sent for energy recovery, or remain uncollected.
Our philosophy focuses on the effective utilization of such difficult-to-recycle plastics by converting them i

At the same time, the world loses over 2 billion trees annually to meet the demand for timber in the furniture and construction industries—making deforestation the second leading driver of climate change.

The Environment for Waste Reduction: This process diverts substantial amounts of plastic waste from landfills, incinerators, oceans, and public spaces, directly reducing plastic pollution, also providing a durable alternative to natural wood, the demand for timber is reduced, which helps combat deforestation and protects ecosystems and biodiversity.

YC_OneLiner: Refash Tiles transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 800 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Target_Countries: Kenya, Rwande, South Sudan , Tanzania , Uganda
Science_Inputs: RefashTiles leverages material science and engineering to convert low-value plastics into durable construction tiles. We optimize polymer blending ratios and apply controlled thermal-melting and compression processes, we transform mixed and flexible plastics which are normally unrecyclable into strong, UV- and water-resistant products. This approach preserves material properties while avoiding toxic emissions from open burning. Our process integrates circular systems thinking while linking plastic collection from informal waste streams directly to high-demand construction outputs. This combination of science-driven processing, systems-based circularity, and market-focused design ensures both environmental impact and commercial viability, creating a scalable model for urban plastic recovery across Africa.
Bold_Characteristics: RefashTiles is bold because it challenges the assumption that low-value plastics cannot be economically recycled at scale. Instead of producing low-demand products, it converts problematic plastics into high-value construction tiles, linking waste directly to urban infrastructure. If successful at scale, this model could divert thousands of tonnes of plastic from landfills and waterways, create sustainable jobs for waste pickers, reduce reliance on carbon-intensive cement, and provide affordable building materials across African cities. By proving that waste can become a core input for durable
Problem_Addressed: Urban centres in Uganda and other rapidly growing African cities such as Kampala, Gulu, Nairobi, and Dar es Salaam face a growing plastic waste crisis. Uganda generates over 600,000 tonnes of plastic annually, yet less than 10% is recycled. Low-value plastics like LDPE films (bags, sachets), HDPE containers, and mixed household plastics dominate urban waste streams but are largely unrecyclable due to contamination and low resale value. They clog drainage channels, worsen flooding, pollute waterw
