Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on a combination of materials science, simple manufacturing technology, and systems thinking. Scientifically, it relies on the principle that many types of plastic can be reheated, reshaped, and compressed without losing their structural properties. By sorting, cleaning, melting, and molding plastic waste, we are able to convert it into durable materials suitable for furniture, tiles, flower pots, and interior décor products.
Technically, the process uses low-cost, adaptable equipment such as shredders, molds, and heat-press or extrusion systems. This allows production to remain accessible in low-resource environments while still meeting functional strength and durability requirements. Product design focuses on modular shapes that reduce material waste and allow easy replication.
From a systems perspective, the solution connects three problems into one system: plastic pollution, unemployment, and lack of affordable products. Plastic waste becomes raw material, com
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it challenges how plastic waste, unemployment, and production are usually treated as separate problems. Instead of seeing plastic as pollution, we treat it as a raw material. Instead of seeing communities only as consumers, we position them as producers. And instead of relying on expensive industrial systems, we prove that high-value products can be made using simple, accessible technology.
Problem_Addressed: City plastics and rivers waste management
Beneficiaries:
The primary beneficiaries of our solution are youth, women, and low-income communities who gain skills, income opportunities, and access to affordable products. By turning plastic waste into valuable products, the project creates jobs in collection, processing, production, and sales, directly improving livelihoods.
Communities also benefit from a cleaner environment, as plastic waste is removed fr

Science_Inputs:
The insight behind out solution is data driven. Recent statistic indicates that global plastic production doubled from 2000 to 2019 reaching 460 million tons and without action, this is anticipated to triple by 2050. This uncontrolled production of plastics is accelerating the triple planetary crises i.e. Climate crisis, biodiversity crisis and the pollution crisis.

Kisumu City generates an estimated 250 to 400 tons of waste daily out which 23 tons are plastics, only 39% of the waste is collected and 15% recycled. This leaves nearly 5 tons of plastic leaking into our environment including our freshwater Lake...Lake Victoria.
Bold_Characteristics:
The assumption that our solution challenges is the negative mindset that art cannot be used to address the pollution crisis considering the magnitude of plastic pollution which is a global threat. At Eco-arts we believe that every small counts and every milestone can be achieved through the small steps and actions taken daily.
The other assumption it challenges is the fact that plastics are good resources for making awesome eco-friendly products, but not waste as people view them. At Eco-arts, we believe that waste is wealth.
Problem_Addressed:
The plastic waste problem we are addressing is the waste crisis leaking into our landfills and water bodies like Lake Victoria in Kisumu County, Kenya.
 Lake Victoria is a vital resource for communities in and around Kisumu, but the Lake faces numerous environmental threats such as plastic pollution, climate change and unsustainable practices.
The Lake supports the livelihoods of over 40 millions people across Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania.

The people who are mostly affected by the pollution crisi
Beneficiaries:
The beneficiaries from our solution include:

1. Informal waste pickers-They directly deliver plastics to space and in return get paid for their work which boosts their financial strength and economic status.

2. Municipalities-Our municipal benefits because upcycling transforms environmental liabilities into economic assets thus reducing the waste that is sent to municipal landfills.
Team_Info:
Eco-arts is a startup composed of 4 members, i.e 2 males and 2 females.
The team is made of dedicated volunteers who are environmental champions working on SDGs such as climate action, life below water and life on land.
Our team don't only volunteer at Eco-arts, but they are also part of volunteerism in other climate initiatives across the globe.
Description:

We believe in the power of art as a vital tool in addressing issues around climate change, biodiversity protection and plastic pollution.

We upcycle plastics into decorative arts for aesthetical appeal. Our handmade products are used in homes, offices, restaurants and events.

YC_OneLiner: Green Roof Africa  transforms HDPE containers into recycled pellets for manufacturing through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 300 tonnes ...
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on the scientific and systems level insight that certain widely discarded plastics, particularly HDPE and polypropylene, retain strong mechanical and thermal properties even after recycling, making them suitable for long life structural applications when processed correctly. Unlike plastics such as PET, HDPE and polypropylene can be repeatedly melted and reformed through extrusion without significant loss of strength, flexibility, or durability, especially when stabilised with appropriate additives.
From a technical perspective, the solution applies controlled thermal extrusion and corrugation, a proven manufacturing process, to transform shredded plastic waste into roofing sheets with predictable thickness, strength, and load distribution. The corrugated geometry increases stiffness while minimising material use, allowing recycled plastic to meet functional requirements normally served by metal roofing. The addition of UV stabilisers and fire retardants addresses
Bold_Characteristics:
Green Roof Africa is bold because it challenges the assumption that plastic waste management and affordable housing must be treated as separate problems. The dominant approach assumes plastic waste should be downcycled into low value products or exported, while housing materials must rely on steel, cement, or imported inputs. This project demonstrates that mismanaged plastic packaging can be transformed locally into core housing infrastructure, not temporary or low value goods.
If Green Roof Africa succeeds at scale, plastic waste will shift from being an environmental liability to a strategic
Problem_Addressed: Green Roof Africa addresses the problem of mismanaged plastic packaging waste, specifically plastic bottles and rigid containers made from HDPE and polypropylene, which accumulate in coastal and urban communities in East Africa, where waste leakage into rivers and the ocean is high yet waste collection and recycling systems are weak. Plastic bottles and containers are commonly dumped in open spaces, drainage channels, and informal dumpsites. During heavy rainfall, this waste is washed into river
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries are informal waste workers and community collectors, who gain stable demand and income for plastic waste. Coastal and urban communities benefit from reduced pollution and cleaner living environments. Low income households benefit from access to affordable and durable roofing materials. Municipalities and local authorities benefit from reduced plastic leakage and lower was
Team_Info: Green Roof Africa is led by Iradukunda Kevin Jonathan (Founder & Lead Engineer), responsible for technical design, manufacturing development, and strategic direction, and Ishimwe Karekezi Guy Gael (Co-Founder & Operations Lead), responsible for waste sourcing, community engagement, and pilot deployment. Together, the team combines engineering expertise with strong local operational capacity to deliver a scalable climate and housing solution.
Description:
Green Roof Africa transforms mismanaged plastic packaging waste into durable, affordable roofing sheets designed for African climate conditions. The solution collects locally available plastic bottles and rigid containers made from HDPE and polypropylene, processes them through cleaning, shredding, and thermal extrusion, and manufactures corrugated roofing sheets that can directly replace conventional iron sheets.

YC_OneLiner: Green Energy Holding Group transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through fuel conversion, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 263 tonnes annually
Target_Countries: Angola, Ghana, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, South Africa
Science_Inputs: Our solution integrates high‑temperature electrolysis, thermal energy storage, and molecular hydrogenation into a modular system that closes the plastic waste loop while remaining self‑sustaining. The Solid Oxide Electrolyzer Cell (SOEC) operates at 700–850 °C, producing hydrogen with high efficiency. The HydroNova Matrix Chamber applies laminar vortex dynamics to restructure plastic‑derived hydrocarbons into Tier‑6 safe Blue Diesel. Double‑Loop Concrete Silos act as thermal batteries with 90–98% efficiency, charging from solar PV and exothermic reactions, then discharging to drive a Stirling engine that converts 800 °C heat into electricity for the SOEC stack. An Atmospheric Water Generator supplies distilled water, eliminating external dependence. This closed‑loop design removes 720 kg of plastic daily, generates its own energy and water inputs, and delivers a scalable, plug‑and‑play footprint for circular fuel production.
Bold_Characteristics: The Plastic Zero 75 kW plant is bold because it reimagines plastic waste as a feedstock for clean energy, not a liability. It challenges assumptions that recycling requires large centralized infrastructure, that Africa must import solutions, that renewables are too intermittent, and that water scarcity limits electrolysis. Instead, it proves plastic can be converted into Tier‑6 safe Blue Diesel through modular, plug‑and‑play systems powered by SOEC stacks, thermal concrete batteries, Stirling engines, and Atmospheric Water Generation. If scaled, each plant removes 720 kg of plastic daily, deli
Problem_Addressed:
Geography
Southern Africa focus, with corridor reach across Pan‑African coastal and inland hubs.

Hotspots include urban centers (Johannesburg, Cape Town, and Durban) and coastal regions where plastic leakage into rivers and oceans is most severe.

Rural areas are also impacted, as informal dumpsites and burning practices release toxins into soil and air.

Waste Stream

Industrial plastics: offcuts, rejected

Description: Our solution is a modular 75 kW Plastic Zero plant that transforms plastic waste into clean, Tier‑6 safe Blue Diesel while generating its own power. The system integrates a containerized refinery with an Armmoniel SOEC Gold stack for high‑efficiency electrolysis, a HydroNova Matrix Chamber for molecular hydrogenation, and a Stirling Engine powered by Double‑Loop Concrete Silo CCCAES thermal batteries. YC_OneLiner: Individual  transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 1,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: Our solution is based on the insight that low-value plastics can be recycled at scale when material properties, processing methods, and collection systems are co-designed for local conditions. By applying material characterization, simplified pre-treatment, and decentralized processing, we enable consistent recycling of plastics typically excluded from value chains. Integrating informal collectors into a data-supported system improves material quality, recovery efficiency, and overall circularity.

It combines material innovation, decentralized processing, and informal sector integration to transform waste into standardized raw materials for local manufacturing. Unlike conventional approaches that treat collection, recycling, and design separately, this solution reimagines the entire plastic lifecycle, turning a major environmental problem into economic and social opportunity at scale.

Science_Inputs:
HopeCycle Solutions applies material science and circular systems thinking to convert post-consumer PET and rigid plastics into durable, safe spectacle frames. Recycling plastic requires precise sorting, cleaning, and thermal processing to preserve material integrity, which ensures frames are strong, lightweight, and suitable for optical use.

Our approach integrates behavioral insights by engaging youth collectors and communities in structured waste recovery, creating reliable feedstock and incentivizing participation. Unlike conventional recycling, which often produces low-value pellets with uncertain markets, our model links plastic recovery to high-demand health products, creating a closed-loop system that is economically sustainable, environmentally beneficial, and socially inclusive.

The process combines local recycling technology, design-for-use, and community-driven supply chains, allowing scalable production while maintaining quality standards suitable for clinical and retail

Unlike conventional recycling, which often produces low-value outputs or requires export markets, we convert plastic waste into high-demand, health-related products—affordable spectacle frames—linking environmental sustainability directly to social impact.

YC_OneLiner: PlastiRevive transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 400 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: PlastiRevive is built on the insight that plastic waste is not a collection problem alone, but a systems failure driven by weak incentives and poor market linkages. Research and field data show that when waste collection is paired with direct, immediate rewards, participation rates increase significantly. PlastiRevive applies behavioural economics by using digital incentives (points, cash-equivalent rewards) to change disposal behavior, while technology (mobile app, QR verification, data tracking) creates traceability from collection to processing. Localized processing reduces transport costs and carbon emissions, making recycling economically viable.
Bold_Characteristics:
PlastiRevive challenges the assumption that recycling in Africa must remain informal, charity-driven, or government-dependent. Instead, it treats plastic waste as a distributed economic asset and waste pickers and citizens as value creators, not beneficiaries. It shifts recycling from cleanup to income-generating infrastructure.

Problem_Addressed:
PlastiRevive addresses the growing plastic waste crisis in urban Ghana, particularly in Accra and other rapidly urbanizing cities. Ghana generates over 1.1 million metric tons of plastic waste annually, yet less than 5% is recycled. The dominant waste stream consists of post-consumer plastic packaging, water sachets, PET bottles, food wrappers, and household plastics which are improperly disposed of due to weak collection systems and limited recycling incentives.

Beneficiaries: PlastiRevive primarily benefits informal waste workers, urban and coastal communities, and municipal authorities. Science_Inputs:
Skilpack Ltd is a top innovator in Uganda, known for creating biodegradable hair extensions from banana fibers through its Banafine Biohair innovation. The company utilizes textile science, material science, and engineering to refine banana pseudostem fibers into smooth, lightweight strands that prevent itching and irritation, thereby avoiding carcinogens and scalp issues commonly associated with synthetic hair. The process begins with the extraction of fiber using a decorticator, followed by wet chemical processing using modern processing machines to create hair products in various colors.

Banafine hair extensions are breathable and non-toxic, enhancing wearer comfort while reducing environmental impact. They are fully plant-based and biodegradable, contrasting with harmful plastic alternatives that linger in the environment. Skilpack combines agricultural waste processing and beauty innovation to lead in sustainable beauty manufacturing in Uganda, emphasizing aesthetics and performa

This innovation changes how we view agricultural waste as a valuable resource for premium products, aiming to reduce plastic pollution in the beauty industry.

Science_Inputs:
Scientifically, paper is made from cellulose fibers, a renewable and biodegradable material that naturally decomposes into organic matter, unlike plastic polymers that persist in the environment for hundreds of years and break into harmful microplastics. This makes paper bags significantly less damaging to soil, water, and living organisms.

Technically, Umurava Clear Ltd uses simple, scalable paper-conversion and bag-forming processes that require less complex infrastructure than plastic manufacturing and recycling. These processes can be powered locally and adapted to small- and medium-scale production, making them suitable for African contexts.

From a systems perspective, our solution fits into a circular economy: paper bags can be reused, recycled, or composted, and their production supports local supply chains rather than imported plastics. By aligning with Rwanda’s environmental policies and market needs, we create a system where sustainable packaging is accessible, legal, and e
Bold_Characteristics:
This is a BOLD idea because it transforms an environmental restriction into a scalable economic and environmental opportunity.

Instead of treating plastic bans as a limitation, Umurava Clear Ltd boldly addresses the root of the problem by locally replacing plastic bags at scale, not just reducing their use. In a context where plastic is still cheaper, familiar, and widely traded informally across Africa, investing in local paper-bag manufacturing challenges the status quo and shifts market behavior.

The idea is bold because it:

Redesigns the packaging system, not just consumer habits

YC_OneLiner: Joelex Uganda Limited/KEZA WATER transforms PET bottles into sustainable packaging through digital collection platform, serving municipalities and local government, targeting 3,200,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs:
KEZA is built on a systems insight: single-use plastic persists not because people prefer waste, but because refill infrastructure is missing. In water distribution, packaging — not water — is the primary driver of plastic pollution.

By redesigning the system around reuse cycles, KEZA applies circular economy principles where one durable asset replaces dozens of disposable ones. Each reusable container substitutes approximately 1,600 single-use bottles over its lifespan, preventing plastic waste before it exists. This upstream prevention approach delivers significantly higher environmental impact per unit than downstream recycling, while remaining economically viable in African urban contexts.
Bold_Characteristics:
KEZA challenges the assumption that plastic pollution must be managed after disposal. The bold idea is that plastic waste can be designed out of everyday consumption systems entirely, even in rapidly growing African cities.

If KEZA succeeds at scale, it would demonstrate that affordable, refill-based distribution can replace single-use packaging without relying on behavior change, subsidies, or complex recycling systems. This would shift cities away from linear consumption toward reuse-first infrastructure, preventing millions of plastic bottles annually and redefining how essential services
Problem_Addressed:
Urban centres in Uganda generate large volumes of single-use plastic water bottles every day, primarily from households, small businesses, gyms, clinics, and institutions that depend on packaged drinking water. These bottles form a high-leakage waste stream because they are lightweight, low-value, and poorly collected. As a result, they accumulate in drainage channels, informal dumpsites, and water bodies, including the Lake Victoria basin.

Municipal waste systems are not designed to recover th
Beneficiaries:
Urban households and small businesses seeking affordable, safe drinking water without reliance on single-use plastic

Gyms, clinics, and institutions that consume large volumes of bottled water

Municipalities and communities, through reduced plastic leakage, cleaner public spaces, and less strain on waste systems

Urban and peri-urban populations, through local job creation and improved environme

Description: KEZA Water is a scalable refill and reuse infrastructure that replaces single-use plastic water bottles with durable, reusable 20-litre containers distributed through a deposit-return model. Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs: Polymer composite studies serve as the foundation for the solution. Polymer composites are lightweight and strong, with properties that cannot be achieved with a single material (either the matrix or reinforcing material). Fiber reinforcement in the PET matrix enables us to manufacture a strong and lightweight glass fiber-reinforced PET composite tile. This property cannot be obtained by isolating fiber from PET.
Bold_Characteristics: There are preconceptions that waste PET recycling is a sensitive and complex procedure. Recycling waste PET is a simple technique if the chemistry of PET is well understood and process conditions are strictly controlled. Large-scale recycling of waste PET leads to huge job creation, environmental pollution reduction, and income generation.
Problem_Addressed: PET waste is a common type of plastic waste in East Africa, particularly in our country, Ethiopia, and South Sudan. Solid waste is generated by water bottling firms, beverage industries, fruit processing enterprises, and, in some cases, hospitals (during medical packaging). Waste polyethylene terephthalate landfills have ramifications for the general public and community, pet owners and neighbors, children and pets, the environment and wildlife, local governments and municipalities, property man
Beneficiaries: The solution primarily benefits PET waste workers, low-income SMEs that use pavement tiles, unemployed youths in the region, and communities living in the waste landfill area.
Team_Info: Teams consisting of two women and one man.
Description: The idea is to eliminate PET landfills by recycling and producing glass fiber-reinforced PET composite tile products. It involves waste PET collection, segregation, shredding, melting, incorporation of reinforcing material (glass fiber) and fillers, and molding. The composite product outperforms current products in terms of strength, weight, and production costs.

Venture_Name: Research world partnerships Limited /FutureLife Research Foundation
YC_OneLiner: Research world partnerships Limited /FutureLife Research Foundation transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through plastic waste processing, serving underserved communities, processing 50 t...
Science_Inputs:
The scientific and systems-based insight behind TIDES–PLASTICS is that plastic leakage into aquatic ecosystems is driven less by a lack of recycling technology and more by system failures at the point of generation, handling, and early movement, particularly in water-adjacent environments. Research and field evidence show that PET, HDPE, and LDPE are technically recyclable using low-tech processes, but feedstock quality and recoverability are determined upstream by human behaviour, spatial dynamics, and logistics rather than downstream processing capacity.

From a systems perspective, plastics enter Lake Victoria through predictable physical pathways shoreline accumulation zones shaped by wind and wave action, drainage outlets that funnel runoff during rainfall, and fish landing sites with high consumption but limited waste evacuation options. Intercepting plastics at these high-leakage nodes is far more efficient than attempting recovery once materials are dispersed in open water or m
Bold_Characteristics:
First ,assumption that plastic leakage from water-adjacent communities is too diffuse, informal, or costly to integrate into viable markets. The venture demonstrates that bays, islands, drainage outlets, and fishing routes are not peripheral problem areas, but predictable, high-yield interception points.
Second, assumption that fishermen and island communities are beneficiaries of clean-up programmes rather than active operators within circular value chains. By a compensated “plastic fishing” activity and using existing fishing vessels for return-trip backhaul,fishermen as logistics partners a
Problem_Addressed: Communities along Lake Victoria—specifically bays, islands, landing sites, and adjacent mainland urban catchments in western Kenya—generate high volumes of PET, HDPE, LDPE, and mixed plastic waste from households, hospitality venues, fish landing sites, markets, transport hubs, schools, public spaces, and fishing-related activities. PET bottles and flexible packaging dominate the leakage profile due to high consumption and low recovery rates in water-adjacent settings. It remains fragmented and
Beneficiaries:
Primary beneficiaries include:

Fishing communities and boat operators, who gain additional income while reducing plastic interference with fishing gear and nearshore ecosystems.

Island and shoreline communities, particularly youth and women, engaged in paid collection and segregation activities.

Local recyclers and manufacturers, who benefit from improved access to cleaner, more predictable pla
Team_Info:
The TIDES–PLASTICS venture shall be led by FutureLife Research Foundation, in strategic partnership with Research World Limited Liability Partnership (RWLP), combining venture leadership, implementation science, and operational delivery expertise required to transition from pilot validation to a scalable, market-ready circular venture.
Venture Leadership (Full-time)
The venture shall be led by an implementation science and circular systems specialist with extensive experience in waste segregation, containment, traceability, regulatory compliance, and system design across mainland, bay, island,
Description:
TIDES–PLASTICS is a venture-stage circular economy solution designed to intercept plastic waste before it enters Lake Victoria and convert it into reliable, market-ready material streams. The idea is to treat bays, islands, landing sites, and drainage-linked shorelines as early interception points rather than end-points for clean-ups, and to connect these high-leakage zones directly to recycling and manufacturing markets.

The solution is grounded in material science, circular economy principles, and systems thinking. Research in polymer and composite materials shows that recycled thermoplastics can be reinforced with natural fibres derived from agricultural residues to produce composite materials with improved stiffness, durability, and usability. Fibres from materials such as cassava peels and corn husks act as fillers and reinforcement agents, allowing a reduction in overall plastic content while maintaining the strength and functionality required for reusable food packaging. When properly processed, these fibre–plastic composites are suitable for moulding into plates, containers, and trays designed for repeated use.
From a systems perspective, the solution addresses a structural gap in current waste management approaches. In many African contexts, post-consumer plastic waste and agricultural waste are managed as separate streams, even though they coexist geographically. This separation leads to plast
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea is bold because it challenges the assumption that plastic pollution in Africa can only be addressed through bans, clean-up efforts, or large-scale recycling infrastructure. Instead, it treats plastic waste as a material that can be redesigned, combined with local resources, and kept in productive use through practical circular systems.
It also questions the belief that sustainable packaging must rely on imported biodegradable materials or advanced industrial technology. By using locally available plastic waste and agricultural residues, the solution shows that circular materials can
Problem_Addressed: In Nigeria’s urban centres, especially densely populated cities like Lagos and other parts of the southwest, single-use plastic food packaging is a major waste stream. Science_Inputs: From used bottles to luxury items, crafted with eco-responsible techniques, this trendy product combines contemporary aesthetics with ecological awareness, sure to appeal to the most discerning tastes and environmentalists alike. No toxic gases are produced. The bottles are simply cut, dressed, decorated, polished, shaped, and assembled to become refined and luxurious utilitarian or decorative objects. This process also improves the living conditions of employees in the production chain (collectors, sorters, washers, and artisans).
Bold_Characteristics:
The problem to be solved here is how to recycle plastic bottles without creating another source of plastic pollution and while generating paid employment. Plastic bottles are reused for extended periods, unlike the single-use items for which they were originally produced, and they also generate income instead of ending up in the trash.

Furthermore, if production facilities multiply across the country, used plastic bottles will become scarce in order to meet the demand for raw materials.

YC_OneLiner: Bilan Awdal Organization transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through collection and aggregation network, serving women and youth entrepreneurs, processing 12 tonnes
Science_Inputs:
Core Insight: Leveraging Behavioral Economics and Decentralized Systems to Overcome Infrastructure Failure
Our solution is built on a fundamental systems-based insight: in contexts of total infrastructural collapse, a centralized, capital-intensive municipal waste system is not the first or most feasible step. Instead, the most effective intervention is a decentralized, incentive-driven collection network that treats plastic not as waste, but as a low-value but tradeable commodity, activating latent community labor and existing market mechanisms to build a circular system from the ground up.
Bold_Characteristics:
We Are Creating a Market from Nothing. In a place with zero formal waste infrastructure, we are not just collecting trash—we are establishing plastic as a legitimate, traded commodity and building the entire supply chain (collection, logistics, processing, sales) from scratch. This is economic architecture in a vacuum.

We Target the Root, Not the Symptom. Many initiatives focus on clean-ups or recycling plants. We tackle the core market failure: the lack of financial incentive to not burn or dump plastic. Our model changes behavior by making conservation more profitable than pollution.

We Be
Problem_Addressed: In the Awdal region of Somaliland, with the city of Boorama at its heart, a silent crisis unfolds daily. It is a crisis born not of natural disaster, but of a profound systemic disconnect between rapid consumption and complete infrastructural absence. The landscape—once defined by rugged plains and pastoral life—is now increasingly marred by a synthetic tide: the relentless accumulation of plastic waste. Bilan Awdal Organization operates at the epicenter of this emergency, confronting a problem
Beneficiaries:

YC_OneLiner: PLASTI-CYCLE GUINEA transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 100 tonnes
Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on a system approach to plastic circularity, recognizing that waste leakage is not only a technical issue but a market and coordination failure
By integrating material flow analysis, basic polymer sorting knowledge, and locally adapted processing techniques, PLASTI-CYCLE GUINEA optimizes plastic recovery at source. The model leverages existing informal collection networks and aligns them with simple, replicable processing technologies to maximize recovery rates and economic value with minimal capital intensity.
Bold_Characteristics: PLASTI-CYCLE GUINEA challenges the assumption that effective plastic recycling in Africa requires large, centralized, and capital-intensive infrastructure. Instead, it proves that decentralized, community-driven circular models can be commercially viable and scalable. If successful at scale, the project would redefine plastic waste from an environmental burden into a reliable economic resource, while offering a replicable blueprint for coastal and urban African cities facing similar plastic pollution challenges.
Problem_Addressed: In Guinea, plastic waste, particularly single-use plastics such as sachet water bags, bottles, and packaging is widely mismanaged in urban and coastal areas. Due to limited collection infrastructure and weak recycling systems, plastics are dumped in streets, drainage channels, and coastal zones, eventually reaching the ocean. This affects coastal communities, informal waste pickers, fisheries, and urban populations through environmental degradation, flooding, and health risks. The problem is cri
Beneficiaries: Informal waste workers, coastal and urban communities, women and youth groups, municipalities.

YC_OneLiner: SeaCo transforms mixed plastics into biodegradable alternatives through bioplastic alternatives, serving women and youth entrepreneurs
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | Algae/Seaweed materials | AI/ML systems | IoT/Smart systems | → Packaging alternatives
Science_Inputs:
Our core innovation is a calcuim-mediated hydrocolloid cross-linking process. we fuse rigid cassava starch(amylose) with flexible seaweed alginate to create a semi-interpenetrating  polymer network. This hybrid vigor overcomes the brittleness of pure starch and the low strength of pure algae, resulting in a Thermoplastic Alginate-Starch (TAS) that matches the tensile strength of LDPE while remaining fully water soluble.

We solve the CapEx Barrier as our resin is engineered to match the Melt Flow Index(MFI) and sealing temperature of polyethylene. It is a drop-in solution that runs on existing Form-Fill-Seal machines, allowing local factories to swtich inputs without retrofiting equipment.

We turn two waste streams into one solution, We valorize Invasive Sargassum (which harms the blue economy) and Cassava Peels (agricultural waste). creating a circular model that incentivizes coastal cleaning while replacing the un-collectable plastic satchet.
Bold_Characteristics: SeaCo is bold because we reject the incrementalism of better recycling for the satchet economy. We are pursuing the radical, systemic replacement of the continent's most problematic pollutant with a locally engineered, marine-degradeable alternative. We are building the first African solution that allows the convenient of the satchets to survive without the plastic surviving.
Problem_Addressed:
We are addressing the catastrophic failure of flexible single-use packaging in West Africa's Coastal cities, specifically Nigeria and Ghana. This region relies on the Satchet Economy where essentials like water, milk and spices are sold in affordable 60ml - 500ml Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE) packets. 

The core issue is Negative Economic Value. In Lagos alone, 60 million water satchets are discarded daily. Unlike pet bottles, satchets are lightweight and contaminated, making them un-recyclabl
Beneficiaries:
- The coastal & Low-Income urban communites
- Rural Women and Coastal Youth
- Local FMCG Manufacturers

YC_OneLiner: ECO GUARD INNOVATIONS transforms PET bottles into eco-bricks and pavers through construction material production, serving women and youth entrepreneurs, targeting 500 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
EcoGuard’s solution is based on the materials science insight that certain plastics, when heated, can act as a strong binding agent similar to cement. By melting sorted plastic waste and mixing it with dry sand at controlled temperatures, the plastic encapsulates the sand particles, creating a dense, water-resistant composite material. This process produces durable products like paving blocks that are often stronger, more flexible, and less water-absorbent than conventional cement-based alternatives.

From a systems perspective, Eco Guard applies circular economy thinking by linking waste collection, local processing, and product manufacturing into one closed loop. Plastic that would otherwise pollute the environment becomes a raw material, reducing demand for cement, lowering carbon emissions, and creating decentralized, community-based production systems that are affordable, scalable, and suited to African contexts.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because Eco Guard dares to see what everyone throws away as something valuable and powerful. Instead of waiting for perfect systems or expensive technologies, it uses locally available plastic waste and simple processes to create strong, useful products that communities actually need. In doing so, Eco Guard doesn’t just clean the environment, it creates jobs, reduces costs, and shows that real change can start at the community level by turning a problem people live with every day into a practical solution.
Problem_Addressed:
Eco Guard Innovations is addressing the growing plastic waste crisis caused by the widespread use of single-use plastics and weak waste management systems. Large amounts of plastic are discarded daily and end up clogging drainage channels, polluting land and water bodies, and remaining in the environment for hundreds of years. With limited recycling options, much of this waste is burned or dumped, creating serious environmental and health risks for communities.

This problem matters now more tha
Beneficiaries: The people who benefit most from Eco Guard's solution are youth and women in communities that struggle with plastic waste. Young people gain jobs, practical skills, and a chance to earn a living safely, while women benefit from cleaner, healthier environments for their families and access to affordable materials for homes and local businesses. By turning plastic waste into useful products, Eco Gua

Science_Inputs: The solution leverages the scientific and technical insight that PET and polyethylene plastics can be mechanically recycled into polyester fibers, which are suitable for clothing, bags, carpets, and sportswear. By combining sorting, cleaning, and extrusion processes, low-value plastic waste is converted into durable, high-quality PET fibers. The system also integrates informal waste collectors, local manufacturers, and end-users into a circular supply chain, creating a scalable, sustainable, and economically viable solution.
Bold_Characteristics: This solution challenges the assumptions that plastic waste is a low-value burden, that informal waste collectors cannot be integrated into formal supply chains, and that recycling in Africa cannot generate high-value products locally. If successful at scale, it will transform plastic waste into durable polyester fibers for textiles, create stable green jobs, reduce reliance on virgin materials, strengthen local manufacturing, and establish a scalable circular economy model that links environmental, social, and economic impact.

Nairobi generates large volumes of plastic waste daily due to high consumption of bottled beverages, food packaging, and synthetic consumer goods. PET bottles and polyethylene packaging make up a significant portion of the city’s solid waste stream. While some high-value plastics are recovered through informal systems, much of the waste remains uncollected or poorly managed because of limited source segregation and inadequate recycling infrastructure.

Science_Inputs:
BioSanit Ltd leverages agro-waste valorization and circular economy principles to address menstrual hygiene and environmental challenges in LMICs. The solution integrates three key technical insights:

Biodegradable Material Innovation

Pads are produced from banana stems and invasive water hyacinths, which are rich in fibrous cellulose.

These natural fibers provide absorbency, comfort, and structural integrity without synthetic additives.

The product decomposes naturally within months, mitigating plastic pollution and reducing environmental burden.

Sustainable and Low-Impact Production Systems

The manufacturing process is designed for low energy and water use, avoiding chemical treatments and synthetic materials.

By repurposing agricultural residues, the system closes the loop between waste generation and product creation, aligning with zero-waste principles.

The low-tech, modular design allows easy replication and scaling across communities, enhancing local economic resilience.
Bold_Characteristics: BioSanit Ltd represents a bold idea by transforming locally abundant agricultural waste, banana stems and water hyacinths into 100% biodegradable sanitary pads, addressing both environmental and social challenges simultaneously. Unlike conventional pads that take centuries to decompose, BioSanit pads break down naturally within six months, drastically reducing plastic pollution. The model empowers women-led micro-factories, creates local jobs, and builds circular economy value chains, while improving menstrual hygiene for thousands of girls in low-resource communities. By combining sustainabil
Problem_Addressed:
The project addresses the growing plastic waste crisis caused by conventional sanitary pads, which are made of plastic, synthetic fibers, and chemical additives. These products can take over 500 years to decompose, leading to long-term accumulation in landfills, open dumps, and water systems, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) where waste management infrastructure is limited.

In many LMICs, women and girls have limited access to affordable, safe, and eco-friendly menstrual
Beneficiaries: Women and girls in LMICs, Local farmers and suppliers, Communities and the environment

YC_OneLiner: Owanga transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 50 tonnes
Science_Inputs: Our solution is based on the insight that PET plastic, when properly sorted and processed, can be safely reused in durable, non-food applications without loss of performance. Using controlled 3D printing allows us to standardize quality while working with variable waste inputs. From a systems perspective, we link two broken systems that normally operate separately: plastic waste management and energy access. By creating steady demand for recovered plastic, we make collection economically viable while reducing dependence on imported materials. Designing the battery casing separately from the electronics also allows plastic components to be reprocessed multiple times, extending material life and reducing overall waste.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea challenges the assumption that plastic recycling in Africa must rely on large, centralized facilities or low-value products. We show that waste plastic can directly support local manufacturing and energy access at community scale. If successful, plastic waste becomes a resource that powers daily life instead of polluting it. At scale, this model could divert large volumes of plastic from dumps and waterways while creating jobs, reducing material imports, and supporting reliable power for small businesses. It proves that circularity can be profitable, practical, and locally owned in c

PET bottles are the most common waste stream because many households rely on bottled water and sachet drinks. Formal collection and recycling systems are very limited, so most plastic waste is dumped in open areas, drains, or rivers, or burned. YC_OneLiner: Lorryit Digital Smart Waste Management transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 480 tonnes annually
Target_Countries: Algeria, Angola, Benin, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cabo Verde, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Cote d'Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Egypt, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Eswatini, Ethiopia, Gabon, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Kenya, Lesotho, Liberia, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania , Mauritius , Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Niger, Nigeria, Rwande, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, South Sudan , Sudan, Tanzania , Togo, Tunisia, Uganda , Zambia , Zimbabwe
Science_Inputs:
Systems-Based Insight (The Logistics Bottleneck):
Our core insight is that Africa's plastic crisis is not a collection problem, but a transport problem. Informal pickers are efficient at scavenging but inefficient at transport (limited by trolley capacity). Our system decouples collection from transport, allowing pickers to focus on high-volume recovery while trucks handle the movement.


Technical/Scientific Validation:
The solution has undergone a formal Technology Audit with the University of Johannesburg’s Process, Energy & Environmental Technology Station (UJ-PEETS). The audit verified our technical specifications for:  

Asset Tracking Algorithms: The ability to digitally classify waste streams (separating PET, HDPE, and LDPE) at the point of collection.

  
Data Integration: Generating real-time "Waste Information Reports" for municipalities, filling the critical data gap in the National Waste Management Strategy regarding informal sector volumes.
Bold_Characteristics:
The Assumption We Challenge:
We challenge the assumption that Africa needs "more waste pickers" or "more recycling bins" to fix the plastic crisis. We believe the collection network already exists (the 5,000+ informal pickers in Tembisa), but it is failing because it is disconnected from logistics.


The Change at Scale:
If LorryIt succeeds, we do not just clean up one township; we create a "Virtual Waste Fleet" for the entire continent. We prove that you don't need millions of dollars in government trucks to manage waste. You just need to digitally connect the informal "trolley economy" to th
Problem_Addressed:
Geography:
 We address the "First-Mile" logistics crisis in Tembisa (Ekurhuleni, South Africa), a high-density urban township where rigid municipal services struggle to access narrow streets.

Waste Stream:
 The specific problem is Post-Consumer Plastic (PET & HDPE). While valuable, these plastics are voluminous but lightweight ("air"), making them economically inefficient for informal waste pickers to transport manually using trolleys.

Actors Affected:
Informal Reclaimers (Waste Pickers): They
Beneficiaries:
Informal Waste Workers & Urban Municipalities

Households: Have direct access platform for recycling that integrate recycling value chain to one digital channel with educational information on how to recycle plastic and other recyclable materials. 

Informal Waste Workers (Reclaimers): They benefit directly by overcoming the "logistics barrier," allowing them to sell bulk volumes and increase thei
Description:
The Solution :
LorryIt is a digital Smart waste "First-Mile" logistics platform that acts as the "Uber for Plastic Waste." We aggregate fragmented plastic supply from informal waste pickers and households in high-density townships (starting in Tembisa) and connect them to independent truck owners for bulk transport to recyclers.

 A waste picker with a full load of PET/HDPE uses the app to request a pickup instead of walking kilometers to a depot.

YC_OneLiner: PlasticPipe Africa transforms HDPE containers into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving rural farming communities, processing 75 tonnes
Science_Inputs:
The scientific and technical insight behind our solution is that thermoplastic materials, such as HDPE, LDPE, and PP, can be melted, reshaped, and reinforced to create durable, high-quality pipes. These plastics, when properly sorted, cleaned, and processed, have mechanical strength, chemical resistance, and durability suitable for water supply, sewerage, and irrigation applications.

The process uses low-cost extrusion and moulding technologies that are scalable and accessible to community-level operations. By converting plastic waste into standardized pipes, the system demonstrates a circular economy approach: waste materials are transformed into functional, marketable products without significant environmental harm.

This insight combines materials science, engineering, and systems thinking, showing how locally sourced plastic waste can meet real infrastructure needs while generating economic and environmental impact.
Bold_Characteristics:
This is a bold idea because it directly transforms a widespread environmental problem into a practical, high-impact solution. Unlike conventional recycling projects that produce low-value products, our approach creates durable, marketable pipes from community-collected plastic, addressing both pollution and infrastructure needs.

It is bold in its community-centered approach, paying residents for plastic collection, creating livelihoods, and empowering local participation in the circular economy. The project combines social impact, environmental innovation, and economic viability in a single m
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste is a growing environmental and social challenge in many African communities. Millions of tons of single-use plastics, such as bottles, packaging, and containers, are discarded every year, often ending up in streets, rivers, and drainage systems. This unmanaged plastic causes flooding, clogs sewer systems, pollutes water sources, and harms human health and the environment. Coastal communities are particularly affected, with plastic entering oceans and harming marine life.

Beneficiaries:

Secondary beneficiaries include municipalities, farmers, and local contractors, who gain access to afforda

YC_OneLiner: Individual  transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 1,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: Our solution is based on the insight that low-value plastics can be recycled at scale when material properties, processing methods, and collection systems are co-designed for local conditions. By applying material characterization, simplified pre-treatment, and decentralized processing, we enable consistent recycling of plastics typically excluded from value chains. Integrating informal collectors into a data-supported system improves material quality, recovery efficiency, and overall circularity.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it tackles plastics often ignored by conventional recycling—like sachets and flexible films—using a fully integrated, science-driven circular system. It combines material innovation, decentralized processing, and informal sector integration to transform waste into standardized raw materials for local manufacturing. Unlike conventional approaches that treat collection, recycling, and design separately, this solution reimagines the entire plastic lifecycle, turning a major environmental problem into economic and social opportunity at scale.
Problem_Addressed:
Nigeria faces a growing plastic waste crisis driven by rapid population growth, urbanization, and widespread use of single-use plastics. Millions of tonnes of plastic waste are generated annually, yet only a small proportion is formally collected and recycled. Common plastic wastes such as sachet water packaging, PET bottles, and flexible films frequently end up in open dumps, drainage systems, rivers, and coastal environments, especially in major cities like Lagos, Abuja, and Port Harcourt.

Science_Inputs: Wosteal applies mechanical engineering principles to optimize plastic recycling. High-capacity crushers reduce plastic to uniform sizes, while floating tank screw systems separate materials by density and enable continuous washing. Modular design allows scalable assembly lines adapted to client throughput. Local fabrication ensures maintainability and suitability for African conditions. Integrating crushing, washing, and separation increases efficiency, reduces contamination, and supports reliable circular material flows.
Bold_Characteristics: Wosteal is a bold idea because it transforms plastic recycling in Africa by providing locally engineered, affordable, and scalable machinery. Unlike imported equipment, our modular crushers with floating tank systems are designed for durability, easy maintenance, and adaptability to local conditions. With proven market traction across multiple African countries, Wosteal addresses a critical infrastructure gap, enabling small and medium recyclers to scale operations and advance plastic circularity at a continental level.
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste pollution continues to increase across Africa due to limited access to affordable and reliable recycling infrastructure.

Small and medium-scale recyclers, startups, and community initiatives face major barriers in acquiring plastic recycling machinery. Most available equipment is imported, expensive, difficult to maintain, and poorly suited to local operating conditions. As a result, many potential recyclers are unable to process collected plastic waste, leading to plastic leakage
Beneficiaries: Small and medium-scale recyclers, plastic waste entrepreneurs, and community-based initiatives across African countries benefit most from Wosteal’s affordable, locally manufactured plastic recycling machinery. By increasing access to processing capacity, these stakeholders can scale operations, reduce plastic waste, and generate income while supporting circular economy growth.
Team_Info: Wosteal is led by a founder-engineer supported by fabrication technicians and operations support, enabling in-house design, manufacturing, and delivery of plastic recycling machinery.

Science_Inputs:
Scientific Insight
Material properties: Airline cups are typically made of polypropylene (PP) or polystyrene (PS). These polymers are thermoplastics, meaning they can be melted and reshaped multiple times without losing their fundamental properties.

Recyclability: PP and PS can be shredded, melted, and remolded into new products. Their relatively low melting points (PP ~160–170°C, PS ~90–100°C) make them energy-efficient to process compared to other plastics.

Environmental science: By diverting cups from landfills or open dumping, you reduce microplastic pollution and greenhouse gas emissions from incineration.

Technical Insight
Closed-loop recycling: The system captures waste at the source (airline/airport), processes it, and reintegrates it into the economy as new products.

Waste-to-resource conversion: Instead of treating cups as disposable, the project reclassifies them as raw material for manufacturing.

Process flow:

Collection → dedicated bins on flights/airports.

Sorting
Bold_Characteristics:
What Makes It Bold
Directly tackling airline waste: Instead of focusing on general community plastics, we’re targeting a specific, high-volume waste stream (airline cups) that is usually ignored.

Turning a liability into an asset: We’re reframing plastic cups from “pollution” into raw material for new products, shifting the narrative around waste.

Systems-level change: This isn’t just recycling — it’s building a closed-loop system that connects airlines, airports, recyclers, and communities in a circular economy.

Corporate accountability: By involving the Airlines, we’re pushing a major com

Science_Inputs:
Spex is built on a systems-based insight that plastic waste from food delivery can only be reduced at scale by designing reuse directly into the ordering, logistics, and user-behavior loop, rather than relying on recycling after disposal. Our pilot data shows that behavior changes when reuse is frictionless and digitally enforced. Enterprise users achieved 100% return rates when Smartpacks were embedded into bulk ordering and swap-based delivery.

Technically, Spex combines durable material science (food-grade Smartpacks designed for 300+ reuse cycles), digital lifecycle tracking (Unique Identifier (UID)-based package tracking and return validation), and logistics optimization to make reuse cheaper than single-use plastics. The key insight is that cost, convenience, and accountability, not awareness, drive adoption, and enterprise systems provide the structure needed to lock in reuse behavior at scale.
Bold_Characteristics:
Spex is a bold idea because it challenges the assumption that convenience in food delivery must rely on single-use plastic packages.

The prevailing belief is that reuse is too complex, costly, and behavior-dependent to work at scale in Africa. Spex proves the opposite: when reuse is digitally embedded, operationally enforced, and aligned with enterprise workflows, it becomes more reliable and cost-effective than disposable packaging.

If Spex succeeds at scale, single-use plastic packaging will be designed out of everyday food delivery. Enterprises will cut food and packaging costs, vendors w
Problem_Addressed:
Spex by DercolBags Packaging addresses the growing single-use plastic waste crisis driven by the rapid expansion of online food delivery in urban Africa, starting with Ghana. The primary waste stream includes plastic food containers, takeaway bowls, plastic cutlery, and carrier bags used for daily meal deliveries to offices, campuses, and households.

As online meal consumption rises, especially among the working class and enterprises, millions of plastic packages are used once and discarded. In
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries of Spex are enterprise users and their employees, who gain access to affordable, convenient, and waste-free meal planning while reducing food costs by up to 20-30%. Food vendors benefit by eliminating packaging costs, increasing margins, and accessing reliable bulk demand. Cities and coastal communities benefit from reduced plastic leakage, while waste and logistics partn

YC_OneLiner: Ele-Collection transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through collection and aggregation network, serving rural farming communities, targeting 480 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: The core insight is that plastic pollution persists because most systems cannot process mixed, dirty plastics and because plastic has no economic value at source. Plazrok™ technology overcomes the technical barrier by converting all polymer types (1–7), including contaminated waste streams, into structurally tested aggregate compatible with standard concrete mixes. The systems insight is linking CSR-funded recovery to industrial demand, so plastic becomes a cash-generating resource rather than waste. This creates an alternative income stream that reduces reliance on survival practices such as subsistence poaching and deforestation for charcoal production.
Bold_Characteristics: Ele-Collection is bold not just in approach, but in scale. It is designed to operate at volumes sufficient to eliminate the region’s plastic waste entirely, not manage it indefinitely. By matching recovery capacity to regional plastic output, the model can make landscapes plastic-negative, permanently removing more plastic than is generated. The boldness lies in proving that even in wilderness ecosystems—where recycling has never worked—it is possible to solve the plastic problem for good, while protecting wildlife, strengthening communities, and replacing extractive materials at scale.
Problem_Addressed:
Ele-Collection addresses a landscape-scale plastic pollution crisis in the Victoria Falls–Livingstone–Hwange ecosystem within the KAZA Transfrontier Conservation Area. Plastic waste here is not confined to dumpsites; it is spread across forests, rivers, wetlands, floodplains, and bushland, carried into protected areas by wind, rain, wildlife, and human activity.

The waste stream includes all seven types of plastic, most of which are dirty, mixed, and contaminated—from fishing nets and sachets t
Beneficiaries:
Impoverished communities benefit most, in a country where nearly one-third of the population lives on less than one dollar a day. By giving plastic value at street level through CSR/ESG-funded recovery, Ele-Collection creates immediate income in urban and rural areas, reducing reliance on subsistence poaching, charcoal production, and other survival practices.

Wildlife and ecosystems benefit from

YC_OneLiner: At Hause Limited transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving rural farming communities, targeting 525 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs: The most profound insight is a systems-level change: moving from a Linear Waste Model to a Circular Value Model.The Linear Model (Status Quo): Harvest  Immediate Sale (Low Price) High Loss  High Cost Repurchase.The Systems-Based Shift (At Hause): * Decentralized Storage: Instead of building one $10 million silo that farmers can't reach, At Hause creates 1 million "micro-silos" (the bags) directly in the farmers' homes.
Bold_Characteristics:
The Bold Shift: By providing hermetic technology, they are giving farmers the power of time. In economics, this is called "inter-temporal arbitrage"—the ability to move a commodity from a time of low value (harvest) to a time of high value (lean season).

The Impact: They are effectively providing smallholders with the same market-timing power held by massive global grain conglomerates, but at a cost of just $2.15 per unit.
Problem_Addressed:
At Hause Limited addresses a dual-layered plastic waste problem in Uganda that intersects agricultural productivity and environmental health. Uganda generates roughly 600 tons of plastic waste daily, yet only about 40% to 50% is formally collected. A massive portion of this is discarded agricultural packaging that ends up in drainage systems, contributing to severe urban flooding in cities like Kampala.

The "Kaveera" Persistence: Despite government bans on thin polythene bags (kaveera), low-cos
Beneficiaries: The beneficiaries of the At Hause Limited solution span the entire value chain, from rural Ugandan households to urban markets and international trade partners in the GCC.
Team_Info: Cofounder Sulaiman Miti based in London, UK and our investment director Kizito Nsubuga FCCA based in Kampala, Uganda. And cofounder Lukanga Hakim, a KECTIL alumni.
Description: At Hause moves the needle by treating the bag not as a disposable wrapper, but as a durable agricultural asset. By integrating it with the BAH-FX digital platform, we turn a "waste problem" into a "data and value problem," providing the economic incentive (higher grain prices) that finally makes the transition away from single-use plastics possible.

YC_OneLiner: Sucxeed Projects transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through plastic waste processing, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Science_Inputs: Mvula Drops leverages material science and behavioural insight to prevent plastic pollution. Aluminium is infinitely recyclable, has a high recovery value, and avoids the degradation issues of PET. Research shows aluminium cans are more likely to be collected by informal waste pickers, ensuring circularity. The solution integrates behavioural design—African-inspired branding encourages conscious consumption and environmental stewardship, shifting consumer habits upstream. By combining high-value recyclable materials, circular economy principles, and culturally resonant design, Mvula Drops turns source-reduction into a scalable, science-driven, market-ready FMCG solution.
Bold_Characteristics: Mvula Drops is bold because it challenges the assumption that bottled water must be in PET and that consumers will resist paying for sustainable alternatives. In South Africa, people are accustomed to plastic bottles, yet aluminium cans dominate other beverages. By offering a market-ready, recyclable solution, we shift mindsets and make circular packaging desirable, culturally resonant, and profitable. If successful at scale, Mvula Drops will replace PET with aluminium across FMCG channels, drastically reduce plastic leakage, create inclusive livelihoods, and set a pan-African benchmark for su
Problem_Addressed: Africa, particularly coastal and urban markets, faces a mounting single-use plastic crisis, dominated by PET water bottles. These low-value plastics are poorly recovered, frequently leak into landfills, rivers, and oceans, and overwhelm municipal waste systems. Informal waste pickers earn minimal income from PET, while communities suffer environmental degradation and health risks. Hospitality, tourism, and FMCG supply chains face increasing ESG and sustainability pressures, making plastic reduct
Beneficiaries: Mvula Drops delivers multi-level benefits across African communities. Informal waste collectors gain higher-value income from aluminium recovery, supporting livelihoods and inclusion. Coastal and urban communities benefit from reduced plastic pollution in rivers, landfills, and oceans, improving environmental health. Municipalities gain relief from overburdened waste systems and a model for source

YC_OneLiner: individual transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving youth and young entrepreneurs, targeting 100,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs:
Uganda generates approximately 600–600+ metric tonnes of plastic waste per day across the country.,Over 219,000 tonnes per year of plastic waste nationally

Kampala Metropolitan Area alone generates significant amounts—estimated at 135,804 tonnes/year in one study, or around 150–180 tonnes per day of plastic waste generated in the city.Uganda imports roughly 150,000 metric tons of plastic products annually, much of which enters the waste stream due to limited recycling capacity.
Only ~40–50% of plastic waste generated is collected and managed through formal systems; the remainder largely ends up in the environment (on land, in waterways, drainage systems) or informal dumps

Plastic recycling rates remain very low in Uganda, Some estimates suggest only ~10% or less of plastic waste is recycled.

In specific cities like Gulu City, about 75% of plastic bottles may be collected, but only 11% are actually recycled.

Venture_Name: REFA - Renew Eco Fuel from Africa to the world
YC_OneLiner: REFA - Renew Eco Fuel from Africa to the world transforms HDPE containers into alternative fuel through fuel conversion, serving local SMEs and entrepreneurs, targeting 350 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs:
La solution REFA repose sur des technologies éprouvées, combinées de manière innovante dans un système circulaire intégré. La méthanisation anaérobie est un procédé biologiquement maîtrisé permettant la conversion des déchets organiques en biogaz. La pyrolyse thermique des plastiques, opérée à haute température en absence d’oxygène, permet leur dépolymérisation en fractions énergétiques liquides et gazeuses.

Sur le plan chimique, l’amélioration des carburants repose sur des réactions de substitution utilisant des additifs comme l’ETBE, visant à améliorer la qualité de combustion. Sur le plan systémique, REFA applique une approche d’économie circulaire et de couplage énergie–déchets, intégrant les flux de matière, d’énergie et les acteurs locaux (collecteurs, ménages, communautés). Cette combinaison réduit les pertes, maximise la valeur extraite des déchets et renforce la résilience des systèmes urbains africains.
Bold_Characteristics:
REFA est audacieuse car elle aborde la pollution plastique non comme un simple problème de propreté, mais comme un levier stratégique de transition énergétique et industrielle en Afrique. L’idée rompt avec les approches fragmentées (collecte seule, recyclage mécanique limité) en proposant un système intégré reliant déchets, énergie, emploi et climat.

Elle est également audacieuse par son positionnement africain : une solution conçue pour fonctionner dans des contextes à infrastructures limitées, en s’appuyant sur les acteurs locaux et des unités décentralisées. Enfin, REFA remet en question l
Problem_Addressed:
In West Africa, particularly in urban areas like Ouagadougou (Burkina Faso), plastic waste management presents a major environmental, health, and economic challenge. Single-use plastics (bags, bottles, food packaging) make up a significant portion of urban solid waste, but less than 10% is recycled. The rest is mostly buried, openly burned, or dumped into the environment.

The plastic waste stream is driven by increasing consumption of packaged products, a production system heavily reliant on im
Beneficiaries:
The main beneficiaries of the REFA solution are:

Urban households
→ Improved sanitation through waste collection, reduced neighborhood pollution, and gradual access to cleaner, locally produced energy.

Businesses and commercial entities
→ Regular waste collection and recovery services, lower waste management costs, and support for more sustainable practices.

Description:
REFA (Renew Eco Fuel from Africa to the World) propose une solution circulaire intégrée qui transforme les déchets plastiques et biodégradables en énergie utile, tout en renforçant les systèmes locaux de gestion des déchets en Afrique urbaine.

La solution repose sur un cycle de valorisation unique combinant deux procédés complémentaires. Les déchets biodégradables sont d’abord traités par méthanisation afin de produire du biogaz. Ce biogaz est ensuite utilisé comme source de chaleur pour alimen

Venture_Name: Nicholasmotivates Initiative (NMI) Project Title: Solar-Powered Eco-Friendly Menstrual Health System (SPEMHS)
YC_OneLiner: Nicholasmotivates Initiative (NMI) Project Title: Solar-Powered Eco-Friendly Menstrual Health System (SPEMHS) transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through collection and aggregation ne...
Science_Inputs:
Our solution is grounded in systems based and behavioral insights that link menstrual health, plastic pollution, energy access, and WASH infrastructure. Research shows that single use menstrual products are a significant but under addressed source of non recyclable plastic waste in Africa, especially in off-grid and low resource settings where waste systems are weak.

Technically, the model integrates solar energy systems to power pad banks, lighting, storage, and basic waste handling, ensuring functionality in communities without reliable electricity. From a materials perspective, we prioritize eco friendly and low plastic menstrual products, reducing waste generation at source.

Behavioral insight is central: stigma and lack of disposal options drive unsafe dumping and burning. By embedding education, designated collection points, and community ownership, the system shifts user behavior toward responsible disposal.

At a systems level, the innovation creates a localized closed loop f
Bold_Characteristics:
This is a bold idea because it challenges the assumption that menstrual health and environmental sustainability must be addressed separately. Traditionally, menstrual hygiene programs focus solely on product access, while plastic waste initiatives often overlook socially sensitive, gendered waste streams. Our model integrates menstrual health, renewable energy, and plastic waste management into a single, scalable system.

If successful at scale, it would redefine how communities manage menstrual waste, turning a hidden source of pollution into an opportunity for education, circular economy pra
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste from menstrual health products is a hidden but rapidly growing environmental challenge in underserved African communities. Most disposable sanitary pads are made with high plastic content and are used once, yet in rural communities, schools, IDP camps, correctional facilities, and disability centers, there are little to no systems for safe collection, segregation, recycling, or responsible disposal.

As a result, menstrual plastic waste is commonly burned, buried, flushed into pit

Science_Inputs: Our solution is grounded in systems-based waste management principles that treat plastic waste as a recoverable resource rather than disposable material. By applying source separation, material recovery, and circular economy concepts, the initiative reduces leakage of plastics into the environment while improving recycling efficiency. Community-level collection integrated with existing recycling markets creates a closed-loop system that addresses both environmental pollution and economic incentives for sustained participation.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it shifts plastic waste management from a purely environmental concern to a community-powered economic system. Instead of relying on limited government infrastructure, the solution decentralizes waste recovery, empowers youth and households as active participants in the circular economy, and turns plastic pollution into a source of income and local resilience. By integrating behavior change, market incentives, and scalable community networks, the approach challenges traditional waste models and offers a replicable pathway for cities across Africa.

Science_Inputs: Distribute force generates less pressure than concentrated force; instead of standard shape JerryCan, Anteneh’s JerryCan has torus shape with the same volume as standard jerrycan. At two opposite side of the pipes there are two attached straps used to hold the Anetenh’s Jerry can on your shoulder. This will reduce the pressure of the water by distributing the weight of the water in 360 degrees comparing to the concentrated weight of standard jerrycan, utilize all part of our body for support while avoiding skin contact with the body saving spinal injury and skin damage due to friction.
Bold_Characteristics:
Anteneh JerryCan is a body conformal water transport system that integrates ergonomic load redistribution into the container geometry itself. Unlike conventional rigid jerrycans that concentrate load on the head and neck or one shoulder, the design uses 360 degree weigh distribution that positions water mass near the user’s center of gravity, reducing spinal bending moments and pressure points. The system is engineered for terrain independent use enabling safe transport on steep, muddy and rocky paths where wheeled or animal assisted solutions fail. 
It is manufacturable using low cost PVC wit
Problem_Addressed:
Impact
In many low income regions, poverty prevents household water pipelines forcing people especially women and girls to walk long distances daily carrying heavy jerrycans. This contributes to physical injury, lost education, food insecurity and gender inequality. Carrying 20-25 liters of water causes spinal stress, skin injury and chronic pain while time spent fetching water reduces opportunities for schooling and work.
Beneficiaries: Since Anteneh JerryCan is manufactured in location where there is limited water access the production will be done using local force creating jobs for local residents. One of a very necessary field or skill of work in modern society is plumbing. Since Anteneh JerryCan is manufactured with plumbing equipment like pipe and fitting, anyone with basic training can be qualified to manufacture our produ

Science_Inputs:
The core scientific and technical insight behind Umeme Wetu lies in its inertia-based clean energy generation system, which harnesses kinetic energy through a flywheel mechanism connected to a permanent magnet dynamo. When set in motion, the system stores rotational energy and converts it into electricity, which is then regulated and stored in high-capacity batteries to power machines.

Unlike conventional solar or fuel-based systems, Umeme Wetu uses low-loss energy transmission and magnetic induction, ensuring high efficiency and durability. The solution is modular, maintenance-friendly, and adaptable to various rural and off-grid settings, allowing it to power machinery for agricultural processing, plastic recycling, and water pumping with minimal environmental footprint.

This approach integrates mechanical engineering, renewable energy principles, and circular economy thinking into a robust, decentralized system perfectly suited to Africa’s infrastructure and climate challenges.
Bold_Characteristics:
Umeme Wetu is a bold idea because it challenges the conventional dependency on solar, diesel, or grid electricity by introducing a completely decentralized, inertia-powered energy system that is locally built, low-cost, and scalable. It reimagines clean energy through mechanical innovation rooted in African ingenuity, using locally sourced materials, including recycled metals, to manufacture machines that serve critical needs agriculture, recycling, water access.

What makes it bold is its disruptive simplicity: no need for fuel, complex solar arrays, or external infrastructure. It empowers un
