Science_Inputs:
The insight behind OneUp Hair lies in the intersection of Materials Science and Systems Engineering, specifically targeting the "softening gap" between raw cellulose and high-performance textile fibers.

1. Materials Science: Cellulose Modification
Raw agricultural waste like plantain stems and sisal are rich in lignocellulose. However, in their natural state, these fibers are too brittle and coarse for human skin contact. Our technical insight involves a proprietary organic softening process that modifies the fiber's molecular structure without using the harsh chemical baths (like sodium hydroxide or sulfuric acid) typically found in synthetic manufacturing.

By using a mechanical-organic hybrid technique, we strip away the excess lignin and pectin that cause stiffness, leaving behind a purified cellulose core. This core is then treated with an organic, plant-derived lubricant that reduces the fiber's coefficient of friction, giving it the "slip" and luster of human hair while maintai
Bold_Characteristics:
OneUp Hair is a BOLD idea because it challenges a multi-billion dollar global status quo that has remained unchanged for decades. It is not just a "green" product; it is a fundamental redesign of how beauty is manufactured, consumed, and monetized in Africa.

1. Challenging a "Too Big to Fail" Industry
The global synthetic hair industry is dominated by entrenched chemical giants producing PVC and Kanekalon. Proposing to replace these global standards with agricultural waste from Nigerian farms is a David-vs-Goliath ambition. It is bold to suggest that the "future of beauty" isn't found in a ch
Problem_Addressed:
OneUp Hair addresses this problem by replacing these toxic plastics with circular, plant-based fibers.

Waste-to-Wealth: We use agricultural by-products (plantain leaves, sisal, and pineapple silk) that would otherwise be burned as farm waste.

100% Biodegradable: Our fibers decompose naturally in under 180 days when composted, returning nutrients to the soil instead of polluting it.

Hypoallergenic: By removing the "itch" caused by plastic, we extend the wear-life of the product and eliminate t
Beneficiaries:
1. Female Hairstylists & Beauty Entrepreneurs
This group benefits the most economically. In the current market, stylists are often limited to charging for their labor (hours worked).

The Shift: By using our "Business-in-a-Box" model, they transition into retailers.

2. Health-Conscious African Consumers
Millions of women suffer from Contact Dermatitis (itchy scalp, rashes, and hair loss) caused b

YC_OneLiner: ZERO DECHETS PLASTIQUES EN CI transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving underserved communities, targeting 500,000 tonnes annually
Science_Inputs:
Le fondement de notre solution repose sur une approche systémique de l’économie circulaire, appuyée par des principes scientifiques et techniques éprouvés de gestion intégrée des déchets solides.

Sur le plan scientifique, la solution s’appuie sur la hiérarchie de gestion des déchets (réduction, tri, recyclage et valorisation), visant à limiter l’enfouissement et la combustion, sources de pollution et d’émissions. La prévention des inondations et des risques sanitaires repose sur des données établies liant l’obstruction des réseaux de drainage par les plastiques à la dégradation des écosystèmes et à la propagation de maladies.

Sur le plan technique, le dispositif combine des méthodes de pré-collecte adaptées aux zones à accès difficile, le tri à la source, la standardisation des flux (PET, PEHD, PP) et leur orientation vers des filières de recyclage et de transformation éprouvées (recyclage mécanique, valorisation matière). Les écoles servent de points structurants de sensibilisation
Bold_Characteristics:
Cette idée est audacieuse parce qu’elle dépasse la logique classique de gestion des déchets pour proposer une transformation systémique et territorialisée du problème des plastiques.

Elle est audacieuse d’abord par son changement de paradigme : le déchet plastique n’est plus considéré comme une charge à éliminer, mais comme une ressource stratégique, intégrée dans une chaîne de valeur locale créatrice d’emplois verts et de revenus durables.

Elle l’est ensuite par son ancrage de proximité, en ciblant volontairement les zones à accès difficile et les écoles, souvent exclues des dispositifs for
Problem_Addressed:
Le projet s’attaque à la problématique des déchets plastiques dans les zones urbaines et périurbaines à accès difficile, notamment à Yopougon et dans le Grand Abidjan, où la collecte formelle reste insuffisante. Les plastiques à usage unique (bouteilles, sachets, bidons), produits quotidiennement par les ménages, marchés et établissements scolaires, s’accumulent dans l’espace public, les caniveaux et les plans d’eau, faute de tri et de circuits de pré-collecte efficaces.

Beneficiaries: Les principaux bénéficiaires de la solution sont les communautés locales, notamment les populations des quartiers à accès difficile, qui profitent d’un cadre de vie plus sain et d’une réduction des risques sanitaires et d’inondations. Les jeunes et les femmes en tirent un bénéfice direct à travers la création d’emplois verts et de sources de revenus. Les collectivités voient diminuer la pression s

Venture_Name: AC ELECTRONIC/ Recyclage et valorisation des déchets plastiques recyclables et non recyclables
YC_OneLiner: AC ELECTRONIC/ Recyclage et valorisation des déchets plastiques recyclables et non recyclables  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving was...
Science_Inputs: Our insight: Plastic isn’t “waste” — it’s a reusable material. By sorting, washing, shredding and re-processing agricultural plastic with controlled temperatures and additives, we restore its strength and turn it into new eco-panels. By linking farmers, collectors and manufacturers in one circular system, we reduce pollution and create local value.
Bold_Characteristics:
It’s bold because we turn a serious environmental problem into a profitable circular industry.
Instead of burning or dumping agricultural plastic, we transform it — using low-cost technology — into durable eco-panels and products, creating jobs, reducing imports, cutting pollution, and giving value to something everyone considered “waste.”
Problem_Addressed: Plastic waste like food packaging, agricultural waste, kitchen utensils etc. are widely used in many sectors, but their elimination poses a major environmental challenge, in addition plastic waste is often very mixed (HDPE, PELD, PP, PVC, etc.), which makes their recycling complex and expensive.
Beneficiaries:
Farmers, waste collectors, and local communities benefit the most.
Farmers save money and stop burning plastic, waste pickers earn steady income, and communities get cleaner land, less pollution, and new local jobs — while industries gain affordable, eco-friendly materials.

YC_OneLiner: Eco-Tile Africa transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 500 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs: The solution is based on thermoplastic reprocessing and material densification, where mixed plastic waste is cleaned, shredded, heat-compressed, and molded into durable composite tiles without relying on cement or water. From a systems perspective, the model integrates circular economy principles, combining informal waste collection networks with localized micro-manufacturing hubs. This reduces transport emissions, lowers production costs, and enables scalable deployment in low-resource settings while maintaining material strength, longevity, and environmental resilience
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it redefines plastic waste as critical urban infrastructure, not just recyclable material. Instead of exporting waste, relying on large centralized plants, or producing low-value recycled goods, Eco-Tile Africa embeds recycling directly into city-building and climate adaptation efforts. The approach simultaneously tackles pollution, unemployment, infrastructure gaps, and climate resilience, problems often addressed separately, through one integrated, scalable system designed specifically for African realities
Problem_Addressed: The project addresses the rapidly growing problem of non-biodegradable plastic waste, particularly single-use plastics such as bottles, packaging, and sachets that accumulate in urban and peri-urban areas. Due to inadequate waste collection, limited recycling infrastructure, and low plastic recovery rates, large volumes of plastic waste end up in open dumpsites, drainage systems, rivers, and informal settlements. This leads to severe environmental pollution, blocked drainage, increased flooding,
Beneficiaries:
1. Low-income urban and coastal communities affected by plastic pollution and flooding

2. Informal waste pickers, through stable income and safer working conditions

3. Local governments, via reduced waste management burden and improved infrastructure

4. Residents and small businesses, through access to affordable, durable construction materials

5. The environment, through reduced plastic leaka

YC_OneLiner: Plasticteer Club  transforms mixed plastics into eco-bricks and pavers through construction material production, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 20 tonnes
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
Scientific, Technical, and Systems-Based Insight

Plasticteer Club is grounded in behavioral science, circular economy principles, and community systems thinking. Research shows that youth engagement and peer-led initiatives significantly improve sustainable behavior adoption in communities. By embedding school-based clubs, the initiative leverages social learning and habit formation, ensuring plastic reduction behaviors persist beyond single events.

The project applies material recovery and circular economy approaches by transforming collected plastics into value-added products like eco-bricks and reusable items, creating economic incentives for collection and reuse. Monthly clean-ups, community advocacy, and data tracking form a closed-loop system, linking behavior change, plastic recovery, and local education, ensuring scalable and measurable impact across schools, communities, and regions.
Bold_Characteristics:
What Makes This a Bold Idea

Plasticteer Club is bold because it combines youth-led action, school-based community engagement, behavior change, and circular economy principles into a single, scalable model. Unlike typical clean-up initiatives, it creates permanent structures (clubs) within schools and universities, empowering students to lead monthly clean-ups, peer education, and community advocacy.

The initiative leverages creative storytelling through animated videos, featuring Plasticteer as a hero to inspire young people to act, making environmental responsibility relatable and culturall
Problem_Addressed:
The Problem We Are Solving

Plasticteer Club addresses plastic waste pollution in urban and peri-urban communities in Ghana, with an initial focus on public junior high schools (JHS), senior high schools (SHS), university campuses, and their surrounding neighborhoods. These areas generate large volumes of plastic waste due to high daily activity and reliance on packaged products, yet waste management infrastructure remains limited, leading to plastic leakage into drains and waterways.

Beneficiaries: Primary beneficiaries are students in junior high schools, senior high schools, and universities, who gain leadership skills, environmental education, and hands-on experience in waste reduction. Secondary beneficiaries include unemployed community members and informal waste collectors who join clubs to help with clean-ups and plastic-to-value initiatives, earning part-time income while contributin

YC_OneLiner: Verplast transforms PET bottles into eco-bricks and pavers through construction material production, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 70 tonnes
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs:
Verplast is based on material science and circular economy principles. PET and polyethylene plastics are thermoplastics that can be melted, reformed, and incorporated as binding or filler agents in construction materials without losing structural integrity. Research and past projects, including my work with Enactus KNUST on ReecoPlast, show that PET can enhance concrete durability and improve the strength of pavement bricks. Similarly, plastics can be processed and molded into durable interior décor products, providing long-lasting and aesthetically appealing home items.

The solution also relies on a systems-based approach to waste management. By collecting plastics before they reach landfills, Verplast interrupts the linear waste stream and redirects materials into productive uses. This reduces environmental impact and provides a consistent feedstock for manufacturing, ensuring the solution is both scalable and economically viable.

Finally, Verplast incorporates behavioral and marke
Bold_Characteristics:
Verplast is bold because it challenges the assumption that plastic waste is worthless trash. While others see pollution, I see untapped raw materials for Africa's booming construction and furniture industries. Most recycling initiatives in Ghana stop at collection I want to build the entire value chain from waste collection to finished, market-ready products.

What makes this truly audacious is targeting two high-demand sectors simultaneously: construction materials (a multi-billion dollar industry in Ghana) and interior décor (serving Ghana's growing middle class). The aim is not to create ni
Problem_Addressed: Verplast addresses the growing crisis of single-use PET bottles and polyethylene plastics in urban Ghana. The country generates approximately 1.1 million tonnes of plastic waste annually, yet less than 10% is recycled. Most plastics end up clogging drains, rivers, and lagoons, particularly in Accra, Kumasi, Tema, and Takoradi. These blocked drains have caused catastrophic flooding, including the 2015 Accra floods that killed over 25 people and triggered a fuel station explosion claiming 150+ add
Beneficiaries: Low-income urban communities gain employment and reduced flooding as plastics leave drainage systems. Construction companies access durable, cost-effective building materials. Homeowners and businesses purchase affordable interior décor from recycled plastics. Local governments reduce waste management costs and flood risks. The environment and public health improve as tons of plastic waste are div

Science_Inputs:
Post mining soil waste is contaminated with high levels heavy metals that studies suggest if not  treated could remain for over 1000 years. It was observed from the artisinal  mining sites was these waste  are poorly managed, sometimes used for farming  or construction. The heavy metals causes Malignancies, Renal and hepatic impairment as well as congenital anormalies. This unfortunately happens in the rural communities where majority of illegal mining occurs and with little health facilities there leads to many dire consequences.

A study published by Juan María Terrones-Saeta et all in Oct 2021,  titled Treatment of Soil Contaminated by Mining Activities to Prevent Contamination by Encapsulation in Ceramic Construction , suggests that post mining soil waste can be treated by encapsulation in a ratio 3 contaminated soil to 7 uncontaminated soil into a ceramic. 

Our Innovation weeks to use  treated post mining soil waste by encapsulation according to the EPA standard and plastic waste
Bold_Characteristics: It is a bold idea because heavy metal management post mining is a huge  and expensive challenge currently, associated with strict legislation due to its health and environmental effects. YC_OneLiner: Individual transforms HDPE containers into recycled materials through collection and aggregation network, serving waste collectors and informal workers, targeting 350 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on three key insights

Material science insight: Low-value plastics can be safely melted and compression molded into high-strength composite materials suitable for non-load-bearing infrastructure, offering durability and water resistance superior to concrete in flood-prone areas.

Systems insight: Africa’s plastic waste problem is not only technical but structural. Centralized recycling fails because waste generation, collection, and value creation are geographically disconnected. Decentralized micro-factories realign incentives by processing waste close to where it is generated.

Behavioural insight: When communities see plastic transformed into visible infrastructure they use daily, participation in waste collection increases, improving long-term sustainability and waste segregation.
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea challenges the assumption that effective recycling in Africa must be centralized, capital intensive, and dependent on high value plastics. It proves that even “unrecyclable” plastics can drive a viable circular economy when solutions are locally designed.
If successful at scale, cities would shift from treating plastic waste as a liability to managing it as a decentralized resource for climate resilient infrastructure. Flooding would decrease, informal waste workers would become recognized green entrepreneurs, and African cities would leapfrog traditional recycling models entirely.
Problem_Addressed:
African urban and coastal communities face a severe accumulation of low-value, hard to recycle plastic waste, particularly sachet water packaging, thin plastic bags, and multilayer food wrappers. These plastics are rarely collected by formal recycling systems due to low market value and technical difficulty.

As a result, they clog drainage channels, worsen flooding, pollute coastal waters, damage fisheries, and are often burned or dumped, releasing toxic pollutants. While recycling efforts exis
Beneficiaries:
Low iincome urban and coastal communities, who experience reduced flooding, cleaner environments, and improved infrastructure

Informal waste pickers, who gain safer working conditions, predictable income, and inclusion in the circular economy.


Women and youth, who will be prioritized for employment and entrepreneurship opportunities.

Coastal ecosystems and fisheries, protected from plastic lea

Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs: Our solution leverages the inherent polymer properties of post-consumer plastics (PET, HDPE) to improve the strength, durability, and water resistance of paving stones and construction blocks. A novel process allows mixed and low-value plastics—common in African waste streams—to be converted into high-value polymer additives, overcoming limits of traditional recycling. This creates a circular urban system: plastic waste becomes a reliable input for eco-friendly infrastructure, reducing landfill pressure, lowering cement use, cutting production costs, and supporting scalable local value chains in both waste management and construction.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it flips the conventional view of plastic waste from a nuisance into a valuable construction resource. The key assumption it challenges is that low-value and mixed plastics are unusable or economically unviable, our process proves they can enhance paving stones and blocks. If scaled, it would transform urban waste systems, reduce landfill and waterway pollution, cut reliance on cement, create green jobs, and establish a circular economy linking plastic management to affordable urban infrastructure across cities.
Problem_Addressed: African cities are facing a growing plastic waste crisis driven by rapid urbanization, population growth, and increased use of single-use plastics such as bottles, sachets, bags, and food packaging. Waste management systems have not expanded at the same pace as consumption, leading to poor collection and disposal. As a result, plastic waste is often dumped in open spaces, burned, or washed into drainage channels, rivers, and wetlands. This causes blocked drainage systems, urban flooding, environ
Beneficiaries: Informal waste workers, Municipalities,Construction sector,Environment, etc..

YC_OneLiner: Dunia Bora transforms PET bottles into sustainable packaging through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving coastal fishing communities, targeting 120 tonnes annually
Technologies: Bio-based materials | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Packaging alternatives
Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in material science and systems-level circular economy principles. Cactus biomass contains polysaccharides, fibres, and binding compounds that can be processed into bio-based films and composites with functional properties relevant to packaging.

Our systems insight is that Africa’s plastic problem cannot be solved by recycling alone, but requires upstream material substitution using locally abundant, under-utilised biological resources. By aligning agricultural by-products with packaging demand, the project reduces waste, lowers material costs, and shortens supply chains—making sustainable packaging economically viable in African markets.
Bold_Characteristics:
This idea challenges the assumption that sustainable packaging must be imported, high-tech, or cost-prohibitive for African markets. Instead, it proposes that climate-resilient crops grown in Africa can become the foundation of a new, locally owned packaging industry.

If successful at scale, this approach would shift plastic circularity upstream, reducing plastic pollution before it occurs, creating new bio-material value chains, and enabling African producers to move away from single-use plastics without increasing costs. It repositions agriculture not just as a food solution, but as a mater
Problem_Addressed:
Across African urban and peri-urban markets, single-use plastic packaging—especially flexible sachets and PET used for food and beverages—constitutes one of the fastest-growing and least recyclable waste streams. In countries like Kenya, Nigeria, and Ghana, these plastics are widely used due to low cost and lack of viable alternatives, yet collection and recycling infrastructure remains limited.

As a result, large volumes of food-grade plastic packaging leak into landfills, waterways, and coast
Beneficiaries:
Small and medium-sized food and beverage producers benefit most by gaining access to affordable, locally produced alternatives to single-use plastic packaging, enabling them to reduce plastic waste without increasing costs. Urban and peri-urban communities benefit from reduced plastic leakage into landfills and waterways, improving environmental and public health outcomes.

YC_OneLiner: Rebugs Solutions  transforms mixed plastics into sustainable packaging through plastic waste processing, serving rural farming communities, processing 15 tonnes
Science_Inputs: The scientific and systems-based insight behind Rebugs Solutions lies in the intersection of Polymer Science and Industrial Symbiosis. Instead of viewing plastic as "waste," we treat it as a high-density energy and material source that is currently being "stranded" in the first mile of the agricultural supply chain.
Bold_Characteristics:
Rebugs Solutions is a bold idea because it shifts the focus from "waste management" to "Material Sovereignty" for African farmers.
1. It Challenges the "Centralization" Dogma
Most circular economy models rely on large, expensive centralized factories. Our bold insight is that decentralized, farm-level upcycling is the only way to solve the rural plastic crisis. By miniaturizing industrial processes (thermal compression and wet-molding), we empower the "First Mile the Eléwé ẹran community to handle its own waste without waiting for urban infrastructure that may never arrive.
Problem_Addressed:
For Rebugs Solutions, we are addressing two specific, high-volume waste streams that currently have no formal management system in the Eléwé ẹran community:

The Source: hundreds of years to decompose. Because they are bulky and contaminated with organic matter, traditional recyclers often refuse them.
The Result: Farmers often resort to open-air burning, which releases toxic dioxins, or burying the plastic, which leads to microplastic contamination in the soil and water supply.
Beneficiaries: Smallholder Poultry Farmers and Rural Ecosystems

YC_OneLiner: Precifarm transforms HDPE containers into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving coastal fishing communities, processing 60 tonnes
Science_Inputs: Precifarm is based on a simple idea: equipment doesn’t fail suddenly—it shows warning signs first. By tracking how pumps, irrigation lines, and controllers actually run (hours, power, flow/pressure, faults) and combining that with repair history, Precifarm can spot early problems and predict what will fail next. Then it turns that into clear actions: what’s wrong, which part is needed, and how to fix it—so systems are repaired early rather than replaced.
Bold_Characteristics: Precifarm is bold because it challenges the assumption that “hardware is a one-time sale and failures are inevitable”—especially in Africa. The waste system is already overwhelmed: Africa’s municipal solid-waste recycling rate is about 4%, and average collection is ~55%, even though ~70–80% of city waste is technically recyclable, so most of its material value leaks into dumps or the environment. At the same time, Africa generated ~3.5 billion kg of e-waste in 2022, but only ~0.7% was formally collected and recycled—while clean-energy hardware is scaling fast, with 9.3 million off-grid solar k
Problem_Addressed: In Kenya’s arid and semi-arid counties (such as Kitui, Makueni, Turkana, and Garissa), the rapid adoption of solar-powered irrigation and drip systems is creating a growing but poorly managed waste stream from both plastics and renewable-energy hardware. Smallholder farms depend on plastic-intensive components—drip lines, emitters, connectors, filters, and pump fittings—that often fail prematurely due to clogging, pressure mismatch, UV exposure, and lack of preventive maintenance. At the same ti
Beneficiaries: Precifarm is building a circularity layer for Africa’s agricultural and renewable-energy hardware—systems that rely on plastics but lack diagnostics, repair pathways, and take-back. Neura AI is the frontline: a voice+vision repair assistant that helps technicians and households diagnose faults, select the right parts, and complete repairs safely, rather than replacing entire assemblies. Precifarm

Description:
Precifarm’s idea is simple: make farm and renewable-energy equipment last longer by fixing problems early instead of replacing hardware after failure.

Precifarm is an AI platform that connects solar pumps, irrigation systems, and controllers to monitor how they are actually used in the field. It detects early signs of failure, tells technicians what will fail, why, and what part to fix, and tracks each component through its full life.

What makes it different is that Precifarm not only monitors

YC_OneLiner: Agrobright Foundation transforms HDPE containers into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving women and youth entrepreneurs, processing 80 tonnes
Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in material science and systems design:
•	Technical insight: Agricultural plastics are predominantly polyolefins (HDPE, LDPE, PP), which are highly suitable for mechanical recycling via melting and extrusion without significant degradation. We use proven, low-cost decentralized extrusion technology (e.g., open-source Precious Plastic machines) adapted for rural settings, ensuring safe, durable outputs suitable for agricultural use.
•	Systems-based insight: Traditional recycling fails in rural areas due to low waste density and transport costs. AgriCircle applies circular economy principles by co-locating collection, processing, and redistribution within farming communities, creating a self-reinforcing loop where waste becomes a valued resource.
Bold_Characteristics: It challenges the assumption that effective plastic circularity is only viable in urban or coastal areas with dense waste streams. AgriCircle proves that rural, dispersed agricultural communities – often seen as “too hard” to reach – can achieve high collection rates and meaningful diversion through integrated, value-driven systems. If scaled across Kenya’s and East Africa’s drylands, it could divert millions of tons of plastic from soil and water, restore farmland health, create thousands of green jobs for youth and women, and significantly strengthen climate resilience for small-scale farmer
Problem_Addressed: In Kenya’s semi-arid counties of Kitui, Machakos, Makueni, Embu, and Tharaka Nithi, small-scale farmers face a growing plastic waste crisis. Fertilizer sacks, pesticide containers, mulch films, drip tapes, silage wraps, and seed packaging are vital for farming but persist as waste on farms, rivers, and communal lands. With over 80% of farmers cultivating less than 2 hectares, limited rural waste systems mean plastics are burned, buried, or left to accumulate—releasing toxic fumes, leaching chemi
Beneficiaries: Small-scale farmers , Rural youth and women, Local farming , County ecosystems

All members are fully committed to this initiative, with 100% time allocation from the Director and at least 50-80% from board members during the program period.

•	Daniel Mulonzi Munguti (Director/Chairperson & Project Lead): Background in agricultural development and NGO management. Leads strategy, farmer engagement, and partnerships. Full-time commitment.

YC_OneLiner: SMART FARMING transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through bioplastic alternatives, serving women and youth entrepreneurs
Target_Countries: Burundi, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Rwande, Tanzania , Uganda
Science_Inputs: Our solution is based on a systems-thinking approach that links waste management, sustainable agriculture  and rural development. Scientifically, it applies principles of circular economy, transforming non-biodegradable plastic waste into durable, low-cost irrigation tools. Technically, we use simple, locally adaptable fabrication methods to design manual pumps that require no electricity and are easy to maintain. Systemically, we integrate these tools into smart farming practices that boost climate resilience and empower marginalized groups, especially women and youth within the agricultural value chain.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a BOLD idea because it challenges the assumption that effective irrigation and smart farming solutions must be expensive or imported. It reimagines waste, notably plastic, as a resource, turning a major environmental threat into a tool for resilience and productivity. If successful at scale, this model could transform how smallholder farmers across Africa access affordable agricultural technology, drastically reduce plastic pollution, create thousands of green jobs and shift mindsets toward local innovation and circular economy solutions.
Problem_Addressed:
We are addressing the growing plastic waste crisis in Burundi. Plastic waste, mainly bottles, containers and packaging, accumulates in the environment due to the absence of effective waste collection and recycling systems. This non-biodegradable waste clogs gutters, pollutes soil and poses serious threats to both agriculture and public health.

Smallholder farmers, women and youth, are particularly affected. The polluted environment reduces farm productivity and increases health risks. This prob
Beneficiaries: Smallholder farmers (youth and women), small businesses and entrepreneurs.

If it scales, we can redistribute wealth away from massive monopolistic companies towards communities through maintenance of water infrastructure. Meaning development becomes actually sustainable and not just giving and abandonment of infrastructure.
Problem_Addressed: An estimated 11 million tonnes of plastic bottled water waste ends up in the ocean each year. These bottles do get reused a lot but so much goes into the ocean, into landfill, are burnt in communities releasing harmful gases.
Beneficiaries: Poorest communities in southern and eastern Madagascar by having access to sustainable water and sanitation services (gap) paid for by the profits of the sale of this high end treated water.

Venture_Name: HELCO SOLUTIONS LIMITED (SELF HEALING PLASTIC BOTTLE THAT REDUCE PLASTIC POLLUTION)
YC_OneLiner: HELCO SOLUTIONS LIMITED (SELF HEALING PLASTIC BOTTLE THAT REDUCE PLASTIC POLLUTION) transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through plastic waste processing, serving underserved communities,...
Technologies: Chemical depolymerization | Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems
Science_Inputs:
EMBEDDING HEALING AGENTS

We will use nanomaterials, such as MXene or microcapsules containing a liquid healing agent (monomer), within the polymer matrix of the plastic.

TRIGGERING:

When the plastic cracks or breaks, the damage ruptures the embedded capsules or exposes the nanomaterials to an external trigger, such as humidity, heat, light, or a chemical change.


AGENT ACTIVATION AND BONDING:

The released healing agent flows into the crack in the plastic bottle. The trigger activates the agent, causing a chemical reaction (polymerization) that effectively bonds the broken section in the plastic bottles back together.

RESTORATION:

The healing agent acts like a glue, solidifying to restore the plastic material's structural integrity and strength, sometimes to nearly its original level
Bold_Characteristics:
Our solution is a self healing plastic bottles that repairs itself when cracked or broken. The plastic is embedded with self healing agent that are triggered when plastic is damaged, then glues the material back together

We will use nanomaterials, such as MXene or microcapsules containing a liquid healing agent (monomer), within the polymer matrix of the plastic.

Our idea will help reduce plastic bottles pollution and disposal in the landfills and lakes, since the plastic bottles will be self healing if they cracked or breaks which makes them durable and last longer
Problem_Addressed:
A single plastic bottle can take up to 450 years to break down — and even then, it never truly disappears. Instead, it shatters into microplastics that persist in the environment for generations.

What if we invent a self healing plastic bottles that heals itself when plastic cracks or breaks preventing disposing of plastic bottles to the land fills
Beneficiaries: Consumers (people using plastic in households, factories etc)

Science_Inputs: The solution leverages material science and mechanical processing: plastic waste is sorted, shredded, melted, and molded into construction and institutional products. The hubs use locally serviceable extrusion and compression molding machines, which allow for consistent quality, durability, and termite/weather resistance. By integrating waste collection, recycling, and product manufacturing into one system, the model efficiently closes the loop on urban plastic waste.
Bold_Characteristics: The idea challenges the assumption that plastic waste has no economic value and that sustainable construction materials must be expensive. By turning waste into high-demand products at scale, it redefines urban waste management and infrastructure development. If successful, it can reduce plastic pollution, create green jobs, lower material costs by 20–30%, and catalyze a circular economy across African cities.

The business operates decentralized micro-manufacturing hubs -in Meru, Kenya- that reduce plastic pollution while meeting Kenya’s growing demand for construction and institutional materials.

Urban and peri-urban communities – cleaner streets, reduced pollution, and improved drainage

Construction companies, schools, and governments – access to affordable, durable, and sustainable products

Waste pickers and informal collectors – stable and formalized income opportunities

Environment and climate initiatives – contribution to SDGs 8, 9, 11, 12, and 13 through circular economy practices

Science_Inputs:
Our solution is based on the principle that thermoplastics (HDPE, LDPE, PP) can be softened and act as a binding agent when mixed with granular materials like sand. Shredding ensures uniform melting, while compression molding compacts the mixture into strong, durable pavers. This system leverages material science to transform low-value, contaminated plastics into high-strength building products. The decentralized, small-scale approach optimizes collection, processing, and production locally, reducing energy use and transport, while creating a scalable circular system that turns waste into a useful structural material.
1.Explains scientific principle (plastic binds with sand)
2.Includes technical approach (shredding, molding, compression)
3. Highlights system-level insight (decentralized, scalable, circular)

Unlike standard recycling projects that focus only on high-value plastics or single-use solutions, our project creates a full circular system: it engages communities in collection, applies technical innovation in material processing, and produces scalable, marketable infrastructure products. It is audacious in combining environmental impact, income generation, and local manufacturing, offering a replic

Science_Inputs: The scientific and technical insight behind our solution lies in the thermoplastic properties of post consumer plastics, which can be melted and molded into structurally stable interlocking units for construction. Our interlocks have undergone durability testing, showing up to 75% higher strength than traditional interlocks, and feature a modern, attractive finish that is both functional and aesthetically appealing. By combining material science, load bearing design, and community based collection, the system diverts plastic waste while producing durable, desirable, flood resilient building materials. Unlike standard recycling approaches, this solution links plastic recovery to tangible, high quality infrastructure, demonstrating both environmental and engineering innovation.

This is a bold idea because it challenges the conventional assumptions about both plastic waste and low cost housing solutions in Africa. Traditionally, plastic recycling focuses on material recovery, producing rough or low value products that rarely find practical application. Our approach reimagines plastic as a high quality, durable construction material, combining aesthetics, structural integrity, and social impact.

Science_Inputs: The solution is based on systems thinking and material science insights that recognize plastic as a durable resource rather than waste. Low-density and high-density plastics can be safely melted and compressed into strong, weather-resistant construction materials with a lower carbon footprint than traditional alternatives. The system also applies behavioral insights by incentivizing households and informal waste pickers through direct economic rewards, increasing collection rates without relying solely on enforcement. Decentralized processing reduces transportation costs and makes recycling viable in low-income and underserved areas.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea challenges the assumption that effective plastic waste management must rely on large, centralized infrastructure or government-led systems. Instead, it proves that communities can become producers, not just consumers, of sustainable materials. If successful at scale, this approach would transform plastic pollution into a local economic opportunity, significantly reduce environmental and health risks, and reshape how African cities manage waste by turning an informal problem into a formal, circular economy solution.
Problem_Addressed: The problem is the increasing amount of single-use plastic waste such as plastic bags, sachets, bottles, and packaging materials in urban and peri-urban areas. YC_OneLiner: Kodu Technology transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 24 tonnes
Science_Inputs: The point here is that low-value plastics such as thin film and wrappers are only recycled when you leave two holes at the same time: clean capture and a sure path of processing. These materials normally end up to the environment as they are mixed with food waste, soaked, devalued and collectors disregard them. Our systems approach is based on high footfall locations including schools and Kodu distribution touchpoints that we trust. We introduce the use of simple sorting rules and regular pickups, as well as a small incentive to buy-back, to alter behaviour (in dumping, to returning). We trace weights and contamination and serve a recycling partner with consistent volumes. The plastic is then recycled by the recycler into products such as bins and crates which are returned to the same schools creating a clear visible repeatable closed loop.
Bold_Characteristics: This is ambitious since it will capture the most difficult section of plastic waste, the low value thin film and wrappers which tend to lack a buyer and will end in the drains and dumps. We convert schools and Kodu hygiene bank locations to trusted locations to sell back, put a small buy-back bonus and ensure that off-take by a recycling partner. And then we reuse the recycled goods in the same schools in the form of bins and logistics crates, and then the community members can be made aware of the loop, not merely of its existence. It further connects access to health among women with clean e

Ghana alone has been estimated at 0.84 million tonnes of municipal plastic waste per annum by the country and few quantities are recycled and as such, much of this waste finds its way into open dumps, drains, rivers and coastal environments.

Collecting and recycling plastic reduces pollution, while exchanging waste for tree seedlings restores green cover, improves soil and water retention, and sequesters carbon. By linking community behavior, recycling, and reforestation, the project addresses interconnected challenges waste management, flooding, deforestation, and climate vulnerability creating a local system where plastic recovery directly generates environmental and social benefits.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea is bold because it turns plastic waste into a community resource, challenging the assumption that pollution is inevitable and must be managed only by governments. By linking plastic collection to tree planting, it creates a scalable, behavior driven system. At scale, it could transform communities across Africa, reducing pollution and flooding, increasing green cover, and showing that local action can drive measurable environmental and climate impact.

Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries are local communities in urban and peri-urban areas, including low-income households, market traders, smallholder farmers, waste pickers, and youth groups. YC_OneLiner: SozoFix  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through plastic waste processing, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 15 tonnes
Science_Inputs: Behavioral: 80% discard repairable items due to lack of confidence, not impossibility. Technical: Our Visual Language Model is fine-tuned specifically for material damage detection and repair guidance. Systems: Every repair feeds our dataset, a data flywheel where 87 completed repairs train better AI. We’re targeting 20,000+ annotated scenarios, transforming individual repair knowledge into collective, accessible intelligence that compounds daily.
Bold_Characteristics: We challenge the assumption that plastic waste requires collection infrastructure. In Africa, prevention through accessible repair is more impactful. Boldest bet: AI can democratize expert repair knowledge faster than traditional training. At scale with 10% adoption across urban Africa, we’d prevent 100M+ items from landfills annually, exceeding most recycling programs. We don’t just reduce waste; we fundamentally rewire consumer behavior from disposal to repair as the default.
Problem_Addressed: SozoFix tackles plastic waste in Sub-Saharan Africa by repairing goods instead of discarding them. In Zimbabwe, 80% of tossed plastics are fixable, yet a "confidence gap" leads to toxic burning or landfills. We provide the guidance to close this gap. By extending the life of furniture and appliances, we lower consumer costs and prevent pollution at the source. Join our circular economy.
Beneficiaries: Urban African consumers (middle-income families, DIY enthusiasts) saving money through repair, local repair technicians gaining referrals, informal waste workers managing reduced waste volumes, and communities facing plastic pollution without infrastructure. Secondary beneficiaries: hardware retailers partnering for customer retention, circular economy NGOs using our tool for workshops, and the en

Description: SozoFix turns a photo of a broken plastic item into a personalized repair guide with real-time voice assistance. Our AI diagnoses the damage and generates step-by-step instructions adapted to the user’s skill level. Voice assistant “Alfred” provides live guidance through each repair. For unrepairable items, we suggest creative upcycling ideas. Unlike static manuals or generic AI, we offer visual diagnosis trained on repair scenarios with interactive guidance optimized for African contexts.

Venture_Name: DGB PLASTIQUE MALI SARL/developement du recyclage des dechets plastique PET
YC_OneLiner: DGB PLASTIQUE MALI SARL/developement du recyclage des dechets plastique PET transforms PET bottles into recycled pellets for manufacturing through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving women-l...
Target_Countries: Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Gambia, Guinea, Mali
Science_Inputs: The solution employs a systemic and technology-driven approach to PET plastic waste recycling, adapted to Mali’s environmental and energy challenges. The process begins with targeted collection at five major dumping sites, where waste is sorted, pressed, and shredded using solar-powered mini-preprocessing units. Pre-treated PET is transported via electric tricycles to DGB Plastique Mali SARL, where it undergoes industrial recycling through washing, extrusion, and granulation using a solar-powered line with a capacity of 1 ton per hour. The technology ensures high recovery rates (>90%) and production of uniform recycled pellets. Data monitoring at each stage allows optimization of efficiency, material flow, and quality control. Training of 50 young operators ensures technical expertise, operational sustainability, and scalability of the model.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea is bold because it introduces in Mali an unprecedented industrial PET plastic recycling model fully powered by solar energy, addressing severe electricity shortages and the absence of recycling infrastructure. It challenges the assumption that industrial recycling is impossible or unprofitable in low-resource contexts. If scaled, the project could transform plastic waste management across Mali and West Africa, reduce flooding and environmental pollution, create youth employment, and demonstrate that sustainable, solar-powered circular economy solutions can be replicated in both urban
Problem_Addressed: Mali faces a serious problem with plastic waste management, particularly PET plastics, which are widely used and rarely recycled. This waste accumulates in the streets, gutters, and waterways, causing drainage systems to become blocked and regularly leading to floods, especially during the rainy season. The lack of suitable recycling facilities worsens environmental pollution and health risks. The project aims to develop the recycling of PET plastic waste using solar energy, an innovative and su
Beneficiaries: The DGB Plastique Mali project focuses on valorizing PET plastic waste in Bamako through an integrated and sustainable approach. It aims to collect 5,000 tons of waste per year, clear five major illegal dumpsites, and produce high-quality PET pellets through a fully solar-powered recycling line. The project will provide technical training for 50 young people, with 70% women, and create 50 direct j
Team_Info: The management of DGB Plastique Mali SARL is structured around key functions that ensure effective company management. It consists of a manager who oversees all activities, a recycling director responsible for production and processing, a head of personnel in charge of human resources, a commercial director responsible for sales development and customer relations, as well as an executive secretary who manages administrative and organizational coordination. This team enables organized and efficient company management.
Description: The project proposes an integrated, structured, and sustainable solution for the recycling of PET plastic waste in Bamako, taking into account Mali’s significant energy constraints. It includes the establishment of mini pre-treatment centers at five strategic major dumping sites, each equipped with a solar-powered press and small shredder to optimize waste collection and volume reduction. YC_OneLiner: individual transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 50 tonnes
Target_Countries: Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan, Tanzania , Uganda
Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on the thermoplastic behavior of common post-consumer plastics (LDPE, HDPE, and PP). These polymers soften and rebind when heated, allowing them to act as a durable binding matrix without the need for chemical additives or cement.

When combined with fine mineral aggregates, molten thermoplastics encapsulate solid particles and, upon cooling, form a composite material with:

High compressive strength

Low water absorption

Excellent dimensional stability

Long service life in indoor environments

This composite approach locks plastic into a stable, long-life product, preventing degradation into microplastics.
Bold_Characteristics:
Up to 2–3 kg of plastic waste recycled per square meter of tiles
Reduction in CO₂ emissions per tile produced 
Income opportunities for waste pickers and youth groups
Skilled manufacturing jobs
Local value addition

waterways, or informal dumpsites.
Less than 10% of plastic waste is effectively recycled.
Plastic pollution contributes to environmental degradation, flooding, and carbon emissions
Beneficiaries:
Informal Waste Pickers & Community Collection Groups
High-End Residential Homeowners & Developers
County Governments & Municipalities
The Environment

Venture_Name: GS Objects C/O Grey Area Studios Ghana
YC_OneLiner: GS Objects C/O Grey Area Studios Ghana transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through tech-enabled waste tracking, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 15 tonnes
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials
Science_Inputs:
The core insight behind this solution is that plastic waste failure is primarily a material and process mismatch problem, not a material scarcity problem. Most discarded plastics in Ghana are thermoplastics that remain technically recyclable, but they fail in reuse because they are poorly identified, mixed, or processed without understanding their flow behavior, thermal limits, and additive content.

GS Objects applies material science principles—particularly polymer identification, moisture control, and Melt Flow Index (MFI) analysis—to align waste plastics with the correct manufacturing process. By matching material viscosity and thermal behavior to either injection moulding or additive manufacturing, recycled plastics can achieve performance comparable to virgin materials. Injection moulding is used where consistency, surface quality, and scalability are required, while 3D printing enables rapid prototyping, tooling, and low-cost mould inserts, reducing barriers to iteration.

At a
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it reimagines plastic waste as a high-value local resource rather than a disposal problem, directly challenging conventional recycling models in Africa. Unlike large, centralized industrial systems that are capital-intensive and inaccessible, GS Objects combines advanced material science, decentralized manufacturing, and circular design principles in a small-scale, community-adapted system. It bridges the gap between technical expertise and local action by enabling the reprocessing of diverse thermoplastics into functional, high-quality products using injection moul
Problem_Addressed: This project addresses plastic waste in urban and rural parts Ghana, with a focus on Accra and surrounding residential and industrial areas where plastic consumption is high and recovery systems are weak. The targeted waste streams include post-consumer thermoplastics such as PET bottles, HDPE containers, PP food packaging, and household plastics, as well as post-industrial and production waste including failed 3D prints and offcuts made from PLA, PETG, ABS, TPU, and PP. Although these materials
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries of GS Objects are local communities and informal waste workers exposed to pollution, flooding, and toxic fumes from unmanaged plastic waste. Secondary beneficiaries include small manufacturers, designers, and makers who gain access to affordable, high-quality recycled materials, and educational institutions that can use the system for hands-on training in circular manufac
Team_Info:

The solution combines material identification, cleaning, drying, and Melt Flow Index–guided processing to safely reprocess common thermoplastics such as PP, HDPE, PETG, PLA, ABS, TPU, and TPE. YC_OneLiner: Ecowise bag Solutions transforms mixed plastics into alternative fuel through bioplastic alternatives, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 15 tonnes
Target_Countries: Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, Zambia , Zimbabwe
Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in materials science and systems thinking. Research shows that plastic bags and liners persist for decades, fragmenting into microplastics that contaminate soil and water. In contrast, paper-based fibres bonded with natural starch or plant-based binders can maintain short-term strength while remaining fully biodegradable.

From a systems perspective, EcoWise recognises that waste management infrastructure in many African contexts cannot reliably recover thin plastic films. This makes substitution more effective than recycling for certain products. By designing bags that degrade safely in soil and natural environments, EcoWise reduces dependency on advanced recycling systems.

There is also a behavioural insight: households and small businesses are more likely to adopt sustainable alternatives when they require no behaviour change. EcoWise products are designed to function exactly like plastic bags, enabling easy adoption while delivering environmental benefit.
Bold_Characteristics:
EcoWise challenges the assumption that plastic is unavoidable for affordable packaging and waste containment, especially in African markets. It also challenges the belief that recycling alone can solve plastic pollution, despite low recovery rates for plastic films.

If EcoWise succeeds at scale, millions of single-use plastic bags and bin liners could be eliminated at source, significantly reducing plastic leakage into landfills, rivers, and oceans. This would shift the system from managing plastic waste to preventing it altogether, while enabling local manufacturing, green jobs, and circular
Problem_Addressed:
EcoWise Bag Solutions addresses the problem of single-use plastic carrier bags and bin liners, one of the most common and persistent plastic waste streams in South Africa, with relevance across urban, peri-urban, and rural African communities.

In South Africa, plastic bags and bin liners are widely used in households, small businesses, and informal retail due to their low cost and availability. However, waste collection and recycling systems are uneven, especially outside major cities. As a res
Beneficiaries:
Primary beneficiaries:
Consumers and households — access to plastic-free daily-use alternatives
SMEs and informal businesses — bakeries, shops, and vendors reducing plastic use without operational disruption
Municipalities — reduced plastic waste burden and landfill pressure

Secondary beneficiaries:
Environmental education initiatives and schools — practical demonstration of plastic alternatives

EcoWise Bag Solutions produces plastic-free, biodegradable bin liners and shopping bags designed to replace single-use plastic at the point of everyday use. The products are made from recycled paper fibres combined with natural biodegradable binders, creating a composite material that is strong enough for daily household and retail use, yet capable of safely degrading back into the environment.

EcoWise focuses on two of the most common and high-leakage plastic items: bin liners and shopping bag

YC_OneLiner: Waste2Work  transforms PET bottles into eco-bricks and pavers through compression into building materials, serving youth and young entrepreneurs, targeting 150 tonnes annually
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Construction materials | → Fuel/energy
Science_Inputs: Our solution is built on the principle that thermoplastics such as PET, HDPE, and LDPE can be reheated and reshaped without losing their core structural properties. By shredding and melting this plastic at controlled temperatures, we can mold it into dense bricks and roofing tiles with strong compressive strength, making it a viable alternative to conventional building materials. This reduces the need for energy-intensive cement production.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea is bold because it turns plastic waste—normally burned, dumped, or left to pollute communities—into valuable construction materials. It introduces an alternative to traditional building practices by replacing high-cost, high-emission materials with affordable, durable products made from recycled plastic. By establishing small, scalable micro-factories, it proves that waste can be transformed into a resource for new jobs, affordable housing, and environmental restoration across Africa
Problem_Addressed: Uganda faces a growing plastic waste problem, with large amounts ending up in landfills, drainage systems, and communities. At the same time, the country has a high demand for affordable construction materials. Our project addresses both challenges by converting plastic waste into durable construction products such as bricks and roofing tiles. This solution reduces plastic pollution, supports affordable housing, and creates local jobs through scalable micro-factories in multiple regions.

YC_OneLiner: Individual transforms mixed plastics into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving underserved communities, processing 25 tonnes
Target_Countries: Ghana, Kenya, South Africa, Togo, Uganda
Science_Inputs:
The core insight behind “Plastics for Water” is that plastic pollution is primarily driven by human behavior, not just waste volume. Research from Ghana and other low- and middle-income countries shows that citizens often discard plastics carelessly due to convenience, lack of collection infrastructure, and absence of immediate incentives. Behavioral science demonstrates that direct, tangible rewards for desired actions are far more effective at creating lasting habit change than moral appeals or one-off clean-ups.

The program applies a systems-based approach by linking multiple actors, citizens, water producers, recyclers, and local communities, into a feedback loop where responsible disposal is rewarded, plastics are recycled, and participants see tangible impact in real-time. This loop reinforces positive behavior, makes responsible disposal a visible social norm, and creates a sustainable cycle of collection, reward, and processing.

By addressing the root behavioral drivers and i
Bold_Characteristics:
“Plastics for Water” challenges the assumption that plastic pollution can be solved primarily through clean-ups or infrastructure improvements. Most programs treat waste as a problem to be removed; this initiative treats waste as a behavioral and social challenge, showing that changing daily habits is the key to long-term impact. It also assumes that low-income communities can become active agents in waste reduction when given simple incentives, rather than passive recipients of municipal services.

If successful at scale, this approach could transform how communities manage plastic waste acro
Problem_Addressed:
Ghana is experiencing a severe plastic waste management challenge, particularly in urban and peri-urban areas. The country generates an estimated 840,000 to over 1 million tonnes of plastic waste each year, yet only about 5–9% is recycled. The most dominant and problematic waste stream is sachet water plastic (LDPE rubbers), which is widely consumed due to the affordability of sachet water and limited access to reliable piped water.

Key actors in this problem include sachet water consumers, inf
Beneficiaries: Urban and peri-urban communities benefit most, with cleaner streets, reduced flooding, and better sanitation. Citizens gain rewards and jobs through plastic collection, while recyclers and water producers access a steady supply of clean plastics. Overall, both people and the environment see lasting social, economic, and ecological benefits

Science_Inputs:
The idea uses system-based thinking to reduce single use plastic at its source by combining circular economy principles behavioural incentives and digital infrastructure.
 AI enabled refill beverage fountains intervene at consumption points, tracking bottle use and incentivizes reuse. The system connects retailers, brands, and consumers, creating feedback loops where data guides behaviour, measures plastic reduction, and informs scaling. It integrates hardware, AI software, and circular economy principles for systemic, measurable impact. By studying behaviour trends, such utilisation and carrying of personal bottles, the solution uses these patterns as an advantage.

Our idea uses AI technology, digital infrastructure and circular economy principles to challenge the idea that single use plastic is inevitable and can only be managed downstream. 
Through influencing behaviour trends and taking advantage of a population ready to eco-friendly alternatives this system can help combat single use plastic at the source.
When successful it will reduce plastic leakage in urban areas, change consumption habits and generate data for further circular solutions.
Problem_Addressed:
We aim to address Single use plastic generated from beverage bottles in cities and urban areas. Weak collection systems and informal disposal leads to plastic leakage in drainage systems, eventually into oceans.  The primary actors are local retailers and customers that reinforce a linear system.
The leakage of single use plastic into the environment exceeds recycling and proper disposal capacity. This has developed into a health, economic and environmental crisis for many African countries.

YC_OneLiner: Before the Sea Africa  transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through plastic credit verification, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 60 tonnes
Target_Countries: Cameroon, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria
Science_Inputs:
The solution is based on a systems understanding of plastic pollution pathways. Most marine plastic originates on land and travels through urban watersheds. Intercepting waste upstream is scientifically more effective and cost-efficient than downstream ocean cleanup.
From a scientific perspective, phytoremediation is a proven technique using plants to absorb, stabilize, or break down pollutants such as hydrocarbons and heavy metals, while restoring soil health and local biodiversity.
From a behavioral standpoint, the solution leverages a key insight: repeated visibility of infrastructure reshapes social norms. When collection points are omnipresent and already in use, proper disposal becomes intuitive and socially reinforced.
The system integrates ecology, behavioral science, and local logistics without relying on heavy or expensive infrastructure.
Bold_Characteristics:
This initiative challenges the dominant assumption that plastic pollution must be addressed mainly in the ocean or through heavy technological solutions.
Before the Sea Africa asserts that the most powerful leverage point is upstream—in neighborhoods, daily behaviors, and urban soils.
If successful at scale, the solution would transform waste management in Africa:
Cities would become active buffer zones, not pollution sources.
Watersheds would be protected before reaching the ocean.
Phytoremediation would introduce large-scale ecological restoration across urban and industrial areas.
Behaviora
Problem_Addressed:
Every morning in Yaoundé, plastic bottles accumulate at taxi stations, around universities, churches, markets, and along major roads. Within hours, rainfall carries them into drainage systems and rivers crossing the city, creating a constant flow of plastic pollution toward the Atlantic Ocean.

YC_OneLiner: Kratos Technologies  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving underserved communities
Science_Inputs: Our solution is built on material science and systems engineering principles. PET plastics are processed and repurposed into filament suitable for additive manufacturing, enabling low-waste, localized production. The BMS uses data-driven algorithms to monitor voltage, current, temperature, State of Charge (SoC), and State of Health (SoH), optimizing charging cycles and preventing premature battery degradation. Systemically, the model applies circular-economy design by closing the loop between waste generation, manufacturing, and product use, while incentivizing behavior change through guaranteed waste buy-back.
Bold_Characteristics: Kratos challenges the assumption that recycling in Africa must remain informal, low-value, and charity-driven. If successful at scale, communities shift from being waste generators to raw-material suppliers, plastic becomes a local manufacturing input, and energy storage systems last longer with less environmental harm. At scale, this model can reduce plastic pollution, cut e-waste, create jobs, and position African communities as active participants in advanced green technology value chains rather than end-points of global waste.
Problem_Addressed:
Kratos Technologies addresses the growing challenge of plastic waste mismanagement in South African townships and peri-urban communities, with a specific focus on PET plastic waste generated from beverage bottles, packaging, and household consumer goods. These waste streams are highly prevalent in low-income communities where formal waste collection services are inconsistent or absent.

The primary actors affected include households, informal waste pickers, schools, municipalities, and small bus

Science_Inputs:
1. Fondement scientifique – réduction des impacts environnementaux
Compostage et réduction des gaz à effet de serre
La séparation et le traitement des déchets organiques (au lieu de les enfouir ou de les laisser pourrir en décharge) diminuent fortement les émissions de méthane, un puissant gaz à effet de serre produit par la décomposition anaérobie dans les décharges. Le compostage transforme ces déchets en matière stable qui enrichit les sols tout en réduisant leur potentiel polluant. 
Recyclage pour réduire l’exploitation des ressources
Le tri et le recyclage permettent de récupérer des matières (plastique, métal, papier, verre) qui seraient autrement extraites sous forme de ressources vierges. Cela réduit l’empreinte environnementale liée à l’extraction, au transport et à la transformation des matières premières. 
 2. Fondement technique – efficacité des procédés
 Compostage comme traitement biologique contrôlé
Le compostage repose sur des processus microbiens naturels qui dégradent

Elle transforme la gestion des immondices d’un simple acte de nettoyage en un levier de développement durable, économique et environnemental, dans un contexte où de telles approches intégrées sont encore peu mises en œuvre.

YC_OneLiner: Ecowise bag Solutions transforms mixed plastics into alternative fuel through bioplastic alternatives, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Science_Inputs:
The solution is grounded in materials science and systems thinking. Research shows that plastic bags and liners persist for decades, fragmenting into microplastics that contaminate soil and water. In contrast, paper-based fibres bonded with natural starch or plant-based binders can maintain short-term strength while remaining fully biodegradable.

From a systems perspective, EcoWise recognises that waste management infrastructure in many African contexts cannot reliably recover thin plastic films. This makes substitution more effective than recycling for certain products. By designing bags that degrade safely in soil and natural environments, EcoWise reduces dependency on advanced recycling systems.

There is also a behavioural insight: households and small businesses are more likely to adopt sustainable alternatives when they require no behaviour change. EcoWise products are designed to function exactly like plastic bags, enabling easy adoption while delivering environmental benefit.

The primary waste stream we target is thin plastic carrier bags and household bin liners, which are among the most commonly used and most poorly managed plastic products. These plastics are used daily by households, small retailers, food outlets, and informal businesses, yet they have extremely low recovery and recycling rates.

YC_OneLiner: Africa Ecoword/ projet AKA-GNOE  transforms plastic waste into alternative fuel through fuel conversion, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Science_Inputs:
Our solution is based on controlled biomass carbonization, which transforms organic waste into clean, high-energy charcoal suitable for cooking. By optimizing drying, carbonization, and briquetting processes, agricultural residues and organic waste become a reliable fuel with low smoke and reduced health impacts. This system integrates waste management, clean cooking, and forest conservation into a circular economy model.

This is a bold idea because it challenges the assumption that charcoal must come from trees. If successful at scale, it would decouple household cooking energy from deforestation, significantly reduce pressure on forests, cut emissions, and turn urban organic waste into a valuable energy resource. The solution targets urban and peri-urban communities in Africa—starting in Togo—where charcoal dependence and organic waste generation are high. The project is currently at an early-market entry stage, with a tested product and initial adoption under real conditions.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it challenges the long-held assumption that charcoal must be produced from trees. It demonstrates that organic waste—traditionally viewed as useless or polluting—can fully replace wood-based charcoal as a reliable cooking fuel. If successful at scale, this solution would fundamentally change how African cities manage organic waste and how households access cooking energy. It would significantly reduce deforestation, lower emissions, improve public health, and decouple everyday energy needs from forest destruction, while creating a circular, waste-to-energy system ac
Problem_Addressed: We specialize in organic waste valorization because it is abundant, underutilized, and a major source of pollution when poorly managed. At the same time, over 80% of households rely on traditional charcoal for cooking, making wood fuel a leading driver of deforestation in Togo. By converting organic waste into eco-friendly charcoal, we reduce waste, protect forests, and provide a sustainable and affordable cooking energy alternative.
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries of our solution are households and small restaurants that rely on charcoal for cooking, informal waste collectors who gain new income opportunities, and local communities benefiting from reduced pollution and deforestation. Additionally, municipalities and urban authorities benefit from improved waste management, while SMEs involved in production and distribution gain sus

YC_OneLiner: Trycyclo  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 21 tonnes
Target_Countries: Benin, Burkina Faso, Gambia, Ghana, Guinea-Bissau, Liberia, Mali, Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Togo
Science_Inputs:
TryCyclo is based on the systems insight that plastic recycling efficiency and material value increase significantly when plastics are separated at the source and integrated into a coordinated circular supply chain. Waste management research shows that contamination from mixed waste is a primary cause of low recycling yields and high processing costs in emerging markets.

Technically, TryCyclo uses a digital platform to coordinate households, waste collectors, and recyclers through data-driven scheduling, pricing, and traceability. By introducing financial incentives at the point of disposal, the system applies behavioral economics to encourage source segregation and reduce plastic leakage into the environment.

At a systems level, TryCyclo formalizes fragmented informal waste flows into a circular economy model, improving material quality, stabilizing recycler supply, increasing collector incomes, and enabling scalable, commercially sustainable plastic recovery in African cities.
Bold_Characteristics:
TryCyclo is bold because it fundamentally redefines plastic waste as an economic asset at the point of disposal, rather than a downstream environmental problem. Instead of relying on clean-up, subsidies, or fragmented recycling programs, the model embeds financial incentives directly into everyday waste disposal behavior—shifting millions of small decisions at scale.

The approach is bold in the African context because it digitizes and formalizes an ecosystem that has traditionally been informal and excluded from technology-driven solutions. By integrating households, informal collectors, and
Problem_Addressed:
Plastic waste management in many African cities is fragmented, informal, and economically inefficient. While households and small businesses generate large volumes of plastic waste daily, there is little incentive or structured pathway for source segregation, recovery, and recycling. Most plastic waste is mixed with general refuse, making it difficult to recycle and leading to widespread dumping, open burning, clogged drainage systems, flooding, and marine pollution.

At the same time, informal
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries of TryCyclo are households and small businesses, who gain financial incentives for properly disposing of plastic waste, and waste collectors, who earn reliable income through coordinated collection. YC_OneLiner: A.M DIGITAL HEALTH HUB transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through mechanical recycling into pellets, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 50 tonnes
Science_Inputs: The core insight is that lack of data is the biggest barrier to rural recycling, not just logistics. Our solution is built on a Data-Driven Traceability System using KoboCollect and Python analytics. By digitally logging every kilogram of waste at the point of generation (the clinic), we create the first verifiable dataset on rural medical plastic currents. This 'systems approach' allows us to optimize collection routes and provide environmental compliance reports to health ministries, adding value beyond just the raw material.
Bold_Characteristics: It challenges the assumption that rural medical waste is unmanageable or purely hazardous. We are boldly proving that with the right digital infrastructure, even infectious-risk environments can participate in the circular economy. This is bold because it bridges two disconnected sectors—Digital Health and Waste Management—to create a new 'Green Health' economy in Northern Nigeria, a region typically ignored by circularity investors.
Problem_Addressed: In Bauchi State, rural healthcare facilities generate significant unmanaged plastic waste, specifically single-use medical plastics like IV bags, supplement bottles, and syringe casings. Currently, over 85% of this waste is burned in open pits or dumped in local waterways because there is no formal collection system. The key actors affected are the rural clinics that lack disposal options and the local communities who are exposed to soil and water pollution.
Beneficiaries: Direct beneficiaries are Rural Healthcare Facilities (clinics) which currently lack disposal channels, and peri-urban communities in Azare who are currently exposed to toxic fumes from open burning. Secondary beneficiaries are local youth and informal waste workers who will gain safer, formalized employment through our collection pilot.
Team_Info:
HASSAN AL-MUJTABA JA'AFAR (Founder/Lead): Experienced in Health Information Management and Data Science (Python/KoboCollect). Leads the technical strategy and platform development.

Research Associate (Operations): Handles field data collection and community engagement in Azare.

We are a lean, technical team with deep roots in the Bauchi community, combining IT skills with on-the-ground logistics experience.
Description: We are developing 'Eco-Health Connect,' a tech-enabled reverse logistics system for rural medical plastics. Unlike informal scavengers, we use a digital-first model. We map rural clinics using GPS, provide them with sorting bins for high-value plastics (IV bags, supplement bottles), and use a scheduled retrieval system managed by our central Hub. The collected plastic is sterilized, shredded, and aggregated for sale to industrial recyclers, turning a hazardous waste stream into a traceable suppl
