YC_OneLiner: Ndogo Farms transforms PET bottles into alternative fuel through plastic credit verification, serving waste collectors and informal workers, processing 50 tonnes
Technologies: Biopolymer alternatives | AI/ML systems | → Packaging alternatives
Science_Inputs:
Ndogo Farms’ solution is grounded in circular economy principles, material lifecycle management, and urban agroecology. Scientifically, our approach recognizes that repeated UV exposure, moisture, and soil acidity rapidly degrade low-quality plastic gunny bags, causing polymer breakdown into microplastics that contaminate soil and water systems. By reducing reliance on these short-lived materials and replacing them with durable, reusable systems, we significantly slow plastic degradation and environmental leakage.

Technically, we apply design for durability and reuse by repurposing post-consumer plastic containers into structured gardening systems that extend material lifespan and reduce the need for virgin plastic production. These systems are optimized for small urban spaces, efficient water use, and long-term reuse, lowering both plastic waste generation and carbon emissions associated with plastic burning and replacement.

From a systems perspective, Ndogo Farms intervenes at the
Bold_Characteristics:
Ndogo Farms is bold because it tackles plastic pollution at its source by redesigning how urban households grow food, rather than managing plastic waste only after it has entered the environment. We challenge the widespread use of short-lived plastic gunny bags and disposable containers by replacing them with circular, durable gardening systems.

Our approach is bold in its integration of urban food production, plastic circularity, and ocean protection into a single, community-driven model. Plastic is transformed from a disposable material into a long-term productive asset, while behavior chan
Problem_Addressed: Urban households across Africa increasingly rely on plastic gunny bags and single-use plastic containers to grow food in small spaces. While these plastics are initially affordable and accessible, they degrade quickly under sun, water, and soil exposure. Once damaged, they are discarded into landfills, drainage systems, and rivers. In many urban areas, plastic waste is also openly burned due to limited waste management infrastructure, releasing carbon emissions, toxic fumes, and microplastics th
Beneficiaries:
The primary beneficiaries of Ndogo Farms’ solution are urban households in low and middle-income communities. They gain access to affordable, durable, and eco-friendly gardening systems, reducing reliance on short-lived plastic bags while improving household food security.

Urban environments and waterways benefit as reduced use and improper disposal of plastic bags and containers lowers plastic l

Science_Inputs: The solution is based on systems thinking that addresses plastic waste at the source by reducing single-use packaging rather than relying solely on downstream waste collection. From a technical perspective, it applies food safety and preservation principles to optimize packaging size and material, reducing plastic use while maintaining product quality and shelf life. The approach integrates local supply chains, consumer behavior change, and sustainable packaging practices to create a practical, low-cost model suitable for African contexts.
Bold_Characteristics: This idea is bold because it challenges the widespread dependence on single-use plastic packaging in the informal food sector by proving that small, locally run businesses can operate with reduced-plastic and reusable packaging models. Instead of waiting for large-scale recycling systems, the solution tackles plastic waste at its source while remaining affordable and scalable in low-resource settings. It reimagines how everyday food products can be produced, packaged, and consumed sustainably within African markets.
Problem_Addressed: Mya’s Treats addresses the growing problem of plastic waste generated by single-use food packaging, which contributes to environmental pollution and poor waste management in local communities. Beneficiaries: Urban and coastal communities benefit most from the solution through reduced plastic pollution and improved environmental health. Smallholder farmers, women, and informal workers also benefit through increased income opportunities, safer working conditions, and access to more sustainable food production and packaging systems.

Science_Inputs: The bioplastic system is a nanocomposite film where each component plays a distinct and crucial role in determining the final material properties. The primary matrix is cellulose, while glycerol and nanoclay serve as the plasticizer and reinforcing nanofiller, respectivel
Bold_Characteristics:
The most significant finding in the research of this three-component system is the synergistic effect achieved by combining the plasticizer (glycerol) and the nanofiller (nanoclay) 
.

•
Glycerol alone increases flexibility but compromises strength.

•
Nanoclay alone increases strength but compromises flexibility.

When combined, the glycerol facilitates the dispersion of the nanoclay within the cellulose matrix, leading to a more homogeneous nanocomposite

YC_OneLiner: CleanMowe transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Science_Inputs: The core insight behind CleanMowe is that plastic waste accumulation is not primarily caused by lack of collectors, but by poor coordination and weak feedback systems. Plastic waste generation is continuous, while collection systems are periodic and rigid. CleanMowe applies systems thinking by matching real-time demand (households requesting pickup) with available supply (collectors and vehicles), using simple digital tools to reduce delays and inefficiencies. By logging requests, pickups, and disposal events, the system creates data that improves routing, planning, and accountability, leading to cleaner environments without requiring heavy infrastructure investment.
Bold_Characteristics: CleanMowe is bold because it reimagines waste management as a responsive service, not a static utility. Instead of adding another waste company, it builds a shared digital infrastructure that communities and multiple collectors can use. The model shifts power to residents, giving them a simple way to signal need and demand accountability. In contexts where waste systems are opaque and underperforming, CleanMowe introduces transparency, data, and coordination at the community level. It has the potential to transform how waste services are delivered across African cities by making demand visible
Problem_Addressed: Plastic waste in many African communities is poorly managed due to irregular collection, weak coordination between households and waste operators, and limited accountability. In places like Mowe (Ogun State) and parts of Lagos—Nigeria—households and small businesses rely heavily on plastic packaging for water, food, and daily essentials, yet there is no reliable system to collect this waste consistently. As a result, plastic waste piles up in homes, streets, and drainage channels. When bins over
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries are low- and middle-income households, small businesses, and community institutions in underserved urban and peri-urban African communities where waste collection is irregular or unreliable. These communities benefit from cleaner living environments, reduced health risks from plastic burning and blocked drainage, and improved access to basic sanitation services. Secondary

Description: CleanMowe is a community-based, digitally enabled waste response system that allows households and small businesses to request plastic waste pickup on demand. Instead of waiting weeks for irregular collection or resorting to burning waste, residents can submit a simple pickup request via their phone. YC_OneLiner: BendingForce  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through community education programs, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Target_Countries: Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, South Africa, Zimbabwe
Science_Inputs: The device leverages flexible e-ink technology, laminated PET/holographic overlays, thin-film solar, and solid-state electronics on flexible printed circuits. These mature technologies are combined in a novel layered architecture optimized for durability, low power, and off-grid functionality.
Bold_Characteristics: BendingForce challenges the assumption that digital learning and healthcare tools must rely on fragile, power-hungry electronics. At scale, it could democratize access to essential information in schools, clinics, and refugee settings, reduce plastic waste, and introduce circular, sustainable material use.
Problem_Addressed:
In many underserved communities, short-lifecycle electronics and single-use plastic learning materials create persistent waste streams that are difficult or impossible to recycle. Traditional tablets, phones, and educational aids break easily in harsh environments, become electronic plastic waste, and cannot be locally repaired or processed. This contributes to landfill burden, toxic disposal practices, and lost resources.
BendingForce addresses this challenge by redesigning plastic use toward d
Beneficiaries:
Schools and children in off-grid communities
Rural and urban clinics and healthcare workers
Local SMEs engaged in recycling, assembly, and distribution
Informal waste workers (through collection and upcycling partnerships)
Team_Info: Founder: Yemurai Mlambo — Founder & Product Architect
Description: BendingForce is a flexible, solar-powered learning and healthcare device designed for off-grid African communities. It combines a durable flexible sheet, a low-power e-ink display, simple mechanical interaction, and pre-loaded educational or medical content. The device works without electricity or internet and is robust enough to survive harsh environments. By using recycled plastics in its construction, it reduces waste and creates a circular materials loop. Unlike traditional tablets, it is lo

YC_OneLiner: Associação Os Verdinhos de Moçambique  transforms HDPE containers into recycled furniture through plastic lumber/furniture production, serving waste collectors and informal workers
Science_Inputs: The solution is based on circular economy and material science principles, recognizing that many common plastic polymers can be mechanically recycled and reprocessed into durable products with a long service life. By applying controlled sorting, cleaning, shredding, and heat-based molding techniques, plastic waste is transformed into structurally strong components suitable for school desks. From a systems perspective, the project links waste collection, recycling, and education infrastructure into a single value chain, reducing material leakage into the environment while extending the functional lifespan of plastics.
Bold_Characteristics: This is a bold idea because it tackles two pressing challenges—plastic pollution and inadequate school infrastructure—simultaneously, using a locally driven, circular economy approach. Instead of treating plastic waste as a problem, the project turns it into a valuable resource, creating tangible, high-impact solutions for communities. It challenges conventional waste management and education systems by integrating environmental sustainability, social impact, and innovation into a single practical model. By linking recycling directly to improved learning conditions, it reimagines how communiti
Problem_Addressed:
The project addresses the problem of increasing plastic waste by transforming discarded plastic materials into school desks. In many communities, plastic waste such as bottles, packaging, and other single-use plastics is improperly disposed of due to limited waste management and recycling infrastructure, leading to environmental pollution and health risks.

At the same time, many schools face shortages of durable and adequate classroom furniture, which affects the quality of the learning environ
Beneficiaries: The primary beneficiaries are school children and educational institutions that gain access to durable, affordable desks, improving classroom conditions and learning outcomes. Local communities also benefit through cleaner environments, reduced plastic pollution, and engagement in recycling initiatives that raise environmental awareness. Additionally, waste collectors, local entrepreneurs, and you

Description: Our solution transforms plastic waste into durable school desks through a community-based recycling process. Plastic waste is collected locally, sorted, cleaned, and processed into recycled plastic materials that are used to manufacture school desks. This approach reduces plastic pollution while providing affordable, long-lasting furniture for schools with limited resources. Venture_Name: Préservation et Conservation Verte pour un Avenir Sain et Durable
YC_OneLiner: Préservation et Conservation Verte pour un Avenir Sain et Durable  transforms PET bottles into recycled materials through digital collection platform, serving underserved communities
Science_Inputs: Le projet s’appuie sur des principes scientifiques de gestion intégrée des déchets et de protection des écosystèmes, qui reconnaissent que les déchets plastiques perturbent les sols, les cours d’eau, la faune et contribuent aux changements climatiques.
Bold_Characteristics: Cette idée est audacieuse parce qu’elle s’attaque directement à la pollution plastique à la racine, en remettant en question l’idée selon laquelle les déchets sont inévitables. Plutôt que de se limiter au nettoyage, le projet transforme les déchets plastiques en un levier de protection de l’environnement, d’autonomisation des communautés et de création d’opportunités économiques locales.
Problem_Addressed: La transformation des déchets plastiques en pavés qui constitue un problème majeur pour la Guinée.
Beneficiaries: Au cours des 12 premiers mois de mise en œuvre, notre projet vise à collecter, trier et valoriser environ 5 à 10 tonnes de déchets plastiques provenant des ménages, des espaces publics et des zones naturelles. Cette initiative contribuera de manière significative à la réduction de la pollution plastique locale, tout en sensibilisant les communautés et en promouvant des pratiques durables de gestio
Team_Info:
Agissons aujourd’hui pour protéger demain !
*Pourquoi participer ?*  


✅ Préserver la nature  
✅ Créer de l’ombre et de la fraîcheur  
✅ Protéger la biodiversité  
✅ Inspirer les jeunes à aimer et respecter l’environnement.
Description: la sensibilisation environnementale, la collecte et la gestion durable des déchets plastiques, et leur valorisation à travers le recyclage et la réutilisation. Le projet implique activement les jeunes, les femmes et les communautés locales dans des actions concrètes telles que le tri des déchets, les campagnes de nettoyage, et l’adoption de comportements écoresponsables
